So I decided to put myself to the test: I would spend three nights alone in the woods. I would either learn to control my mind, to see the world for what it is rather than a stage for my personal terror, or I would spend three miserable nights in a near-panic.

I guess the second option wasn't really a great alternative.

item.title: Six Practical Tips to be More Present and Engaged
item.description:
The greatest gift you can give someone is your attention. Everything else follows from that. Being present is the key to developing an irresistible presence, but staying totally engaged is exhausting.

There is no shortcut--you have to build that mental muscle through directed practice and commit to using it--but there are some things you can do to make it a little easier.

item.title: The Magical Power of Attention, Your Most Valuable Asset
item.description:
Most of us don't realize how powerful and valuable our attention is. As a result, we let it leak away and rarely bother to develop it.

Why is it so powerful?

What you put your attention on grows.

Tim Ferriss made this point in The 4-Hour Body when he showed that simply tracking your weight daily, without even attempting to make changes, led to consistent weight loss.

I'm not necessarily saying there is some magical energy created by humans concentrating on specific things. It probably has to do with small micro-behaviors that start to accumulate when we have something in the forefront of our mind. Maybe constantly thinking about your weight leads your brain to subtly adjust weight-loss metabolic processes or change your appetite in small ways.

Or maybe humans are magical.

item.title: If You Don't Show Up, Life Won't Either
item.description:
Work is love made visible. - Khalil Gibran

I have run into two conflicting theories on how success works.

  1. You get lucky. Opportunities come along or they don't. You have to be in the right place at the right time or you just won't get very far. Some people have it, and some people don't.
  2. Success is entirely dependent on your willingness to put in hard work and dedicate yourself to accomplishing what you want.

People who lean on the first explanation usually don't see themselves as very abundant or successful. They feel a lot of frustration around their lives and their dreams, and so they claim that it's all luck to shirk responsibility for what they see as failing.

I have a friend who has done really well, but he gives off a constant anxiety about losing it all. He uses the "I got lucky" argument in a way that absolves him of responsibility for his success, but my guess is he also doesn't want to think it would be his fault if things don't turn out well.

On the other option is a more empowering viewpoint, but it is also often used to offer excuses. For example, insisting your success is based purely on your hard work might give you permission to ignore others' needs and the realities of the world (market demands, consumer interests, quality of your services, importance of outside help and connections, etc.)

So, of course there's a balance.

item.title: Want to Be Irresistable? Be Authentic
item.description: The email exercise that went out last week was on the idea of developing your unique presence, that intangible quality that makes someone irresistible and inspiring. The question ultimately comes down to whether you are engaged in the moment--are you present?--or whether you spend most of your time in your head, worrying, speculating, and second-guessing yourself. If you do the latter, you can experience life fully and live in HD. You hold the key to happiness.

item.title: Life is Not a Dare. Don't Make it One
item.description:
Just because a challenge exists doesn't mean we have to overcome it.

Whoah there! That doesn't sound like the indomitable Warrior Spirit, you might be thinking. Let me explain.

When I was training CrossFit, I remember putting off the training I wanted to be doing (gymnastics, martial arts, parkour, hiking and climbing) for the training I had been convinced was more hardcore/intense/effective/respectable. I was trying to win someone else's game for a prize I didn't even care about, just because it was a challenge issued in a way that got my attention and I have a demon about always being the best.

In my quest to be great at fitness, I adopted CrossFit's standards and tried to master them, even though the end goal wasn't what I wanted. I kept telling myself that I would get around to the stuff I really cared about...once I finished this.

Not surprisingly, this approach to fitness was just one symptom of a deeper tendency to take everything as a challenge. Someone driving an expensive car was a dare to do better. Some guy walking down the street better dressed than I was a challenge. It was toxic:

  • I had to live in the best city (which was always somewhere I was not)
  • I had to have the best girlfriend, which varied between hot, pretty, smart, independent, etc.
  • I had to do the most important, best paying job
  • I had to be the best looking
  • I had to be the most spiritual, and the most patient
  • I had to make the most money

All of these 'bests' were things other people defined, or society in general defined. What made me happy and the 'best' were not the same thing. And when I would occasionally attain 'the best,' it was only a matter of time before someone else or some other segment of society would issue a new dare, and I'd be dissatisfied again.

item.title: The Pains of Transitions
item.description:
Sorry I've been MIA for the last few weeks. A rushed departure from Boulder meant that I wasn't able to write anything. But 30+ hours on the road is lots of time for thinking.

Life has changed in a big way, and I don't yet know what will emerge on the other side of this summer.

Breaking

The last few months have been filled with all sorts of traumas, some big and some small, the hallmark of transition. That, too, is normal. Joseph Campbell pointed out that the hero's journey always requires some kind of death and rebirth. No matter the promised rewards, the death is always terrifying. The hero is faced with obliteration in order to become someone stronger.

item.title: Wake Up: The Not-So-Secret Key to Happiness
item.description: “People say that what we’re all seeking is a meaning for life. I don’t think that’s what we’re really seeking. I think that what we’re seeking is an experience of being alive, so that our life experiences on the purely physical plane will have resonances with our own innermost being and reality, so that we actually feel the rapture of being alive.”- Joseph Campbell We spend so much time worrying about the future or reliving the past that we rarely if ever experience the present.

item.title: The Art of Productivity
item.description: “It's not so much how busy you are, but why you are busy. The bee is praised. The mosquito is swatted.” - Mary O'Connor There is no real connection between work done and productivity. Some of the most productive things people do, which bring the most joy, money, insight, efficiency, or whatever, take very little time and effort. And some of the most useless things take all day to do.

item.title: Two Ways to Play the Game of Life
item.description: "Now we're going to do front flips from high up." My coach pointed at three platforms and the crash mat below them. "You can do either the 2 foot, the 4 foot, or the 6 foot, whichever you're comfortable with." We all went for the 4 foot platform. It wasn't so high and scary as the 6 foot, but it was bigger than the 2 foot so we felt like we were pushing ourselves a bit.

item.title: How to Grow Your Most Valuable Asset
item.description:
An asset is a resource that can create value.

The formal definition by the International Accounting Standards Board is a resource controlled by the enterprise as a result of past events and from which future economic benefits are expected to flow to the entity.

Robert Kiyosaki, the author ofRich Dad, Poor Dad, defines an asset is something that puts money in your pocket, like an investment or the royalties you get on your book, or even the time you spend working at your job (which provides a 1-to-1 exchange of value).

So, what's you're greatest asset? What is the one thing you have that can create an infinite amount of value in the world, both tangible and intangible?

Your mind.

item.title: The Difference Between Nice Guys and Good Men
item.description: As long as you truly respect the other person, you can say whatever you want without hurting them. - A friend It's not a compliment, being called a nice guy. "Nice guys finish last" means that being nice is giving up ambition and assertiveness. Or maybe you've heard, "No more Mr. Nice Guy," meaning, "I'm done holding back my true abilities," or, "Now I'm going to say what I mean.

item.title: The Most Important Skill You'll Ever Learn
item.description:
Go eagerly where the fear is.

You are at a party. Across the snack table, you notice a small crowd gathering around an underdressed guy in jeans and a t-shirt. He turns out to be a well-known science-fiction book agent. Just the person you are looking to meet since finishing your novel. You want to talk to that person. But he looks busy, probably wouldn't appreciate another awestruck peon, and you wouldn't get much talk time anyway. You are convinced it would be a waste of time. So you decide to ask the host for his e-mail address on your way out and write later. You have very good reasons not to introduce yourself.

But then...as you turn back to the friends you came with, you wonder, why are you even making reasons? You aren't making that effort for anyone else in the room. Just this one guy who it would be a great idea not to talk to.

And that's when you know: if you leave this party without introducing yourself, you will leave defeated. You will have found exactly the thing that you need to do to move forward, and shied away from it.

The things you need to do to move forward are always the things you fear doing.

item.title: Sheep, Wolves, and Sheepdogs
item.description:
As the young shepherd lay asleep in the sun, his flock grazed peacefully on the lush slopes of the valley, nibbling on clover, alfalfa, and fescue. Their round bodies dotted the mountainside like so many clouds, merging and parting like the real things.

Without warning, two young wolves burst out of the forest and loped towards the flock. Sheep started bleating in panic and colliding in their panic to escape. The wolves drove right to its center, hoping to scatter it so they could pick off one or two stragglers who got caught in the open, but when the sheep parted, the hunters stopped dead. Waiting for them in the space they'd cleared was a beast of a dog. It's white shaggy coat blended in with the sheep and so it had been guarding the herd from the inside.

The sheepdog rose to its feet and stared at the wolves. Though it was big, it was still only a dog, and these wolves were wild and dangerous. Muzzles wrinkled back in growls, the three sized each other up. Two to one was not good odds, but the sheepdog did not back away. The wolves, realizing their advantage, stepped forward, heads held low to the ground, long yellow teeth bared. Still the sheepdog did not move but only raised its hackles.

item.title: Why Lifestyle Design is Broken
item.description:
When the 4-Hour Body was first released, I was so excited to read about quick, easily applied shortcuts to 'improve' my life and my body. How could I resist the promise of becoming superhuman?

But when I tried to apply the habits, none of them stuck. It wasn't that they didn't work, but they were hacks, not part of a cohesive lifestyle, and hacks are not meant to be permanent or sustainable. The 4-Hour Body in particular reads like a recipe book: you pick your abilities, like building a character in Dungeons & Dragons.

It was Lifehacking applied to people, and while the allure was irresistible, it felt hollow.

item.title: 3 Life-Changing Lessons from Meditating Daily
item.description:
Meditation is such a simple act--you just sit in one place and concentrate on your breathing--yet it is also extremely difficult. It can teach you so much about yourself.

Over the years, I’ve gone through periods when I meditated regularly and times when I just couldn’t bring myself to sit on the cushion. Even when I was meditating, I’ve gone through periods when I was the easiest thing in the world, and I just couldn’t wait to sit. Other times, I would put it off as long as possible, then drag myself to the cushion, and every second felt like an unbearable eternity.

Through all that, I’ve learned a lot of really powerful lessons from sitting and breathing. Three of them have helped me in many other areas of life:

  • My feelings don’t define me or my world
  • Discomfort isn't always bad
  • Routine matters

item.title: Fight: Learn Confidence through Combative Play
item.description:
I’ve been experimenting with a new approach to fitness and movement, inspired by a teacher I greatly respect: Rafe Kelley of Evolve Move Play.

His philosophy is that humans evolved movement rehearsal (aka, play) to learn and refine the skills we needed to survive. Some of these were simply moving about the environment, but for men especially, the ultimate goal was hunting or fighting other humans.

Removing this context from training robs it of some of its most valuable aspects. Competition encourages growth, whether that is with a training partner or an opponent.

Respecting Your Opponent

As a kid, I was unstoppable in contests where there were no losers: straight A's and every academic award I qualified for. But on a sports field, I preferred playing defense to scoring goals. My contribution to winning was keeping my side from losing.

When I started martial arts, it was exciting but also uncomfortable because I had to become more assertive. After getting beaten a few times, I learned to stand my ground. I didn't get violent, but I stopped inviting others to walk all over me.

Play is the perfect place to teach people how to safely assert themselves without hurting others, both physically and emotionally, so that when it becomes important in life, they don’t go overboard.

item.title: 3 Tips to Understand and Inspire Others
item.description:
Have you ever made an agreement with someone which you thought was crystal-clear, only to find them doing exactly the opposite? When you confront them, they respond with, “I didn’t mean it that way,” or, “I thought you meant something else.”

I ran into that problem a lot, and I assumed they were making up excuses. After all, words have specific meanings, right?

Wrong!

item.title: Why Valuing Your Own Happiness Earns You More Respect
item.description:
There is one thing that will destroy a person faster than anything else: inauthenticity.

  • Being devoted to a life that you do not have, instead of being present and engaged in the one that you do have.
  • Constantly putting off, day after day, the things you love.
  • Never disagreeing for fear of offending.
  • Doing what you think you should. Being a ‘nice guy’ or a ‘good girl’.
  • Living up to others expectations of you, instead of living up to your own standards for yourself.

The reason being inauthentic is so self-destructive is because it sends the message to yourself that your beliefs and principles aren't worth expressing, and therefore you aren't valuable or worth listening to.

By presenting ourselves in a way that matches our values, however, we are telling ourselves and others that we think we are worthwhile.

So, by simply doing the things we enjoy, saying the things we hold as true, and acting or presenting ourselves in the ways that reflect who we are, we can build our confidence and sense of purpose.

item.title: This Isn't Going to Be Easy, Is It?
item.description: Chi Ku (Eat Bitter) -Chinese proverb, meaning, "to endure hardship to attain a goal" I have been in Boulder almost a full year now, and it hasn't been easy. I came here thinking it was meant to be. I would show up, tell people that I taught natural movement, and BAM, the money would start rolling in. I would be surrounded by nature and like-minded people, be in the midst of deepening my understanding of ecopsychology, and helping others connect with nature and their bodies.

item.title: The Secret of Authentic Confidence
item.description:
“When people do not respect us we are sharply offended; yet deep down in his private heart no man much respects himself.” -Mark Twain

Life's eternal question: Do you gain self-respect when your worth is proven in the world, or do you prove your worth by cultivating honest self-respect? And can you fake it?

I've noticed a harmful trend in personal development literature, in every field from entrepreneurship to dating, recommending over-the-top confidence, arrogance, and sometimes outright lying. In an attempt to get shy quiet types like me to actually sell ourselves, these gurus assure us that pushy sales tactics are a perfectly legitimate way to interact with people. We need to get over our sqeamishness and man-up, whether it's bulldozing a client to close a deal or asserting dominance to 'pick up' a date.

I disagree. I think that kind of arrogance is symptomatic of people who lack real confidence and so have to rely on a facade of bravado. There is certainly value in rehearsal, routines, and templates, but these should serve as a framework to human interaction, not the basis of them.

Built-in BS Detector

Don't think anyone can tell the difference? The human brain is really good at making judgement about other people based on subtle body language clues that give away a person's true character. For example, after watching a 30 second silent clip of a teacher interacting with a student, research subjects were able to predict how well the teacher would do on their evaluation at the end of the semester. Similar results were found with political candidates (2 seconds of exposure) and doctors facing malpractice suits.

The point is, we're really good at telling when people are inauthentic. (Whether we give credence to what we detect and actually act on our instinct is a matter of trusting your intuition.)

Fake It 'til You Make It

On the other hand, I've also noticed that people tend to assume you have an accurate idea of your own value. That is, if you act like you're "kind of a big deal," they'll treat you that way unless circumstances prove otherwise (they may still challenge or test you to check if you're bluffing, so don't actually lie). If you act like you're not capable or worthy of respect and responsibility, others will treat you accordingly, even if you're actual accomplishments suggest otherwise.

item.title: Are you a Consumer or a Creator?
item.description:
When you imagine yourself living up to your potential, following your bliss, do you envision yourself consuming or creating?

For Warrior Spirit readers, the answer is usually about creation, about self-expression and self-realization, not about buying into someone else's idea of what it means to be successful or happy or accomplished.

The Definition of a Consumer

Someone who primarily interacts with the world by using, eating, reading, or buying things created by others is a consumer. We are all consumers to a certain extent: life must consume resources in order to survive.

In our world, consumption has taken on a much more central role. It runs our economy, which is built around making things for others to consume, and which relies on us to spend constantly. Consumption has been elevated to something sacred. The American dream is  having the ability to consume whatever one wants, as often as one wants.

Hardly a recipe for living up to our potential, unless you believe that a human's greatest potential is to buy a lot.

Remember that media is also a thing we consume. The internet provides limitless chances to consume TV, books, movies, music, blogs, tweets, and funny cat pictures.

The Dangers of Consumption

Of course, we consume partly so we can create. Great writers read great books to fertilize their imaginations. Musicians are influenced by those who came before them. As long as consumption supports creation, there's nothing wrong with it.

But a state of exclusive consumption has powerfully negative effects. Our environment demonstrates clearly how dangerous overconsumption is on a societal scale, but what happens to a person who primarily views the world through the lens of consumption, who thinks of themselves mainly as someone who buys and eats, shops and watches, reads and listens?

Imagine how disempowering it must (does) feel to believe that you are not meant to create things, but only to consume them. You can't even create and shape the environment you need to thrive and be happy. Instead, the best you can hope for is to purchase the pieces of a good lifestyle defined by somebody else.

Scary, isn't it?

item.title: A Millennial Manifesto: The Responsibility to be Great
item.description:
We are the Millennials. Constantly connected, over-educated, and fired with passion, we have been accused of laziness, entitlement, and narcissism.

But we are to inherit the world, a world that is more and more defined by change: entire business platforms rise and fall in the course of a few months. I have no doubt that history repeats itself, but with over 7 billion people, nations with the power to manufacture unfathomable quantities of goods, and an information network that rivals the human brain, I feel justified in saying the world we inherit will be unique in human history.

A Brave New World

Despite all the negative adjectives thrown our way, one thing I have seen among my peers is a truly inspiring degree of passion, a desire to remake the world, to set their own rules and live by their own principles.

We have a powerful vision of a world far different than the one we were born into. Many of us have become distrustful of established power structures. We have seen the green revolution co-opted by corporate interests. Growing up in a globalized world has revealed to us that we cannot blindly pursue power without thought for the repercussions on the rest of the world.

Everything is vulnerable to questioning now, and so many of my friends are unsatisfied with what life has given them.

And lets be honest, life hasn't give them much. Youth unemployment in the US ranges from 20%-30% (depending on the study and the criteria), an abysmally high number. We are underemployed, not unemployable. We came of age into a world that didn't have a place for us, that couldn't utilize us, that expects us to wait idly on the sidelines and be grateful for placeholders like internships and volunteerism.

That, right there, that's the sense of entitlement we're accused of. But shall we instead deign to accept meager returns? I think it's better to constantly be chafing at the bit, striving for more and the chance to make an impact.

In a way, Warrior Spirit is a blog for millennials: it admits a sense of higher purpose, the right to excellence, and even the responsibility to be great. At the same time, it asserts the importance of getting your hands dirty, doing the nitty-gritty, and having the pragmatic know-how to make our vision of the world a reality.

item.title: Do You Trade Happiness to Live 'Right?': Claim Your Light
item.description:
Our deepest fear is not that we are inadequate. Our deepest fear is that we are powerful beyond measure. It is our light, not our darkness that most frightens us. We ask ourselves, Who am I to be brilliant, gorgeous, talented, and fabulous? Actually, who are you not to be? You are a child of God. Your playing small does not serve the world. There is nothing enlightened about shrinking so that other people will not feel insecure around you. We are all meant to shine, as children do. We were born to make manifest the glory of God that is within us. It is not just in some of us; it is in everyone and as we let our own light shine, we unconsciously give others permission to do the same. As we are liberated from our own fear, our presence automatically liberates others. - Marianne Williamson

One of the reasons I moved to Boulder was the belief that it would be a good place to live car-free, to find affordable and plentiful local food, to swear off modern, wasteful comforts (like shoes), and to pursue minimalism by selling my iPad and other non-essentials. Basically, to live the way I believed was Right.

It turned out to be much harder that I thought. I never found the spiritual and emotional fulfillment promised. Instead, I was limited in my activities because I could only go so far without a car, I was always hungry because of my insistence on absurdly high food quality, and I was dirty and ratty because my clothes were so worn out and overused. I was a burden to my friends, always leaning on them to drive me places I couldn't bike.

I thought I was doing the right thing, and that if I held on long enough, things would start to work out (if you've read my book, you know I did this with eating Paleo, and CrossFit). When they never did, I got really frustrated and started to feel bitterness and resentment.

I ended up cleaving so strongly to the way I believed I 'should' be that I completely lost sight of what actually made me happy and ended up undermining my self-esteem and sanity.

On the other hand, I knew a lot of people who weren't terribly worried about doing things right. They simply went after the things that made them feel good, made them happy, or seemed interesting. Their standard was, "Does this make me happy?" and not, "Is this the right way?" I put so much effort into figuring out the right way and following it, but I was lost and floundering. It didn't seem fair that others could be so seemingly lax in their morals but have the peace-of-mind and sense of purpose that I lacked.

One of those people who was living the dream while happily skipping through life in time with her own drummer, was my little sister.

item.title: Happy Thanksgiving
item.description:
Gratitude is hugely underestimated as a practice, but theories as diverse as time psychology and Buddhism encourage us to take some time to reflect on all that we have to be grateful for. Since reading The Time Paradox, I have made a habit of keeping a gratitude journal in order to re-tool how I viewed my past from a childhood of frustration and loneliness to one of self-empowerment and creative insight.

It is also important to show appreciation to the people who help you out. None of us can change the world on our own, so if we are honest with ourselves, we must realize that we owe a lot of our success to others. If we want to continue receiving that support, it's a good idea to offer thanks to those who gave it.

So, in the spirit of Thanksgiving, I offer my appreciation and gratitude.

item.title: Asking for Help
item.description:
One trap that we can fall into is the belief that being excellent means we must never ask for help. After all, if we are heroic, legendary human beings, then we shouldn't need any help, right?

But even the heroes of myth and legend needed help. In fact, in many cases it was their ability to bring people to their cause that allowed them to be successful.

So why are we so reluctant to ask for help? Here are some possible reasons.

item.title: The Last 20%
item.description:
What distinguishes the good from the great? At what point do you go from being alright to being amazing?

I think that the answer to that question is related to how insistent you are on rising past 'good enough' to 'awesome.' For most things in life, 80% is good enough to get by, so most people stop at 80%:

  • You eat right 80% of the time
  • You are 80% committed to your exercise program, but if something comes up, you're happy to skip a day
  • You are happy getting A- grades
  • You follow up with potential leads 80% of the time
  • You listen with 80% of your attention, 80% of the time

In truth, that's fine. For most areas of life, that's all you need. Trying to be 100% in everything would be exhausting. It would require superhuman powers of discipline, scheduling, and sheer determination.

So you know I'm going to say GO FOR IT!

item.title: The Tender-hearted Warrior
item.description:
“Real fearlessness is the product of tenderness. It comes from letting the world tickle your heart, your raw and beautiful heart. You are willing to open up, without resistance or shyness, and face the world. You are willing to share your heart with others.” - Chogyam Trungpa

Chogyam Trungpa said one of the defining traits of the spiritual warrior is a raw, vulnerable heart open to both the beautiful and the tragic. The main character in Dan Millman's The Way of the Peaceful Warrior also learns the importance of allowing himself to open up his heart to both love and grieve when a friend's house burns down.

The Warrior Spirit is not characterized by a stony heart and ultimate pragmatism. It includes--even requires--a sensitive heart that can be inspired to action to protect the wonderful things in the world and to oppose the evil ones.

The Warrior Spirit has a heart so sensitive, "even if a tiny little mosquito lands on it, you feel touched."

But wait! This seems like a liability for us who commit ourselves to taking on the big challenges in the world and our lives. How can we hope to stand up to the manipulations of those with no moral limitations if we are so affected by our own?

Well, the reason there is such suffering and fear in the world is because we hardened our hearts in order to survive the disappointments and hardships of the world. By cutting those things out, we also lost our ability to truly appreciate beauty and wonder and we entered into a cycle of emotional defensiveness: we hide in our comfortable houses that keep out the world, we get to work in protective luxury cars that keep out the noise of the street, we isolate ourselves from the suffering of others so we can pretend it doesn't exist, but we also never understand it.

To understand everything is to forgive everything. - Buddha

item.title: Pursue Your Bliss with Integrity
item.description:
What is it that makes it so hard for us to pursue our dreams? Why is it so frustrating to pull together all the elements of our lives in order to move in the direction we so fervently want to go?

Follow Your Bliss - Joseph Campbell

Joseph Campbell compared the internal psychological journey of our lives with classic myths that have accompanied humans throughout history: from Genesis to Robin Hood, Coyote to Quetzalcoatl, Lord of the Rings to Star Wars, the stories that move us all share common themes.

Campbell believed that these themes were reflections of the stages of human development: if we have the courage to face up to our psychic dragons and to descend into the dark caves and underworlds of our fears and insecurities, we can face the challenges that allow us to become true heroes.

If we lack that courage, then we stagnate, never living up to our potential.

This begs the question of what directs our growth. Campbell's answer would be that it is our dreams, aspirations, and passions, the thing that we were put on this earth to do, that drive us. Follow your bliss unerringly and with commitment, and you will surely become the hero of your myth.

In the myths, the greatest treasures are kept in the darkest caves, guarded by the most fearsome monsters. Likewise, attaining our bliss requires us to face our most ingrained fears and negative habits.

item.title: The Foundation of Empowered Living
item.description:
The first task of the aspiring hero is to train her body. Only when she has learned how to master the external world can she begin the far more difficult task of mastering the internal world.

I've talked before about how success-oriented types tend to discount the importance of health. We tell ourselves that we need to put in as much work as we can, now, when we're young and resilient. Once we've earned our leisure time, we will make up for all the lost sleep, convenient food, drinking, and hours spent hunched in front of a computer.

We tend to ignore just how much this neglect is impacting our ability to do quality work right now.

Today, I want to talk about the importance of fitness in particular, and why a physical practice is so essential to mastering yourself and unleashing your true potential.

Training my body, becoming stronger and more coordinated, has had a huge impact on my sense of self-confidence and courage, and I believe it is an essential thing for any aspiring Warrior to find peace with his or her body. Your body is not just who you are, but it is also your mode of expression in the world. Learn to cultivate it, to appreciate it, and to trust it.

The Training Ground for the Spirit

In many epics, myths, and legends, young heroes spend their early training in physical preparation. This isn't because the physical is more important than the mental and the spiritual, but because it is the most basic realm we must master.

How can a hero expect to overcome the more challenges of ideas, thoughts, principles, motivation, and loyalty if they cannot manage their own bodies and move through the world? Physical competence is a foundational prerequisite for mental and spiritual competencies.

item.title: Are You in the 1%? You Should Be
item.description:
There is an old story of a Roman, Cincinnatus, who was called upon by the Senate in an emergency. Rome's army had been trapped in the field, leaving the city vulnerable to an attack, and the government nominated Cincinnatus as dictator, giving him 6 months of absolute power. He defeated the enemy in 16 days and immediately gave up his office to return to his farm, becoming a legend of civic virtue and restraint.

Most of us associate the word 'dictator' with a corrupt, power-hungry leader, and that is certainly what most Roman dictators were. But the lesson here is that the office of dictator, and later of emperor, was sullied by the corrupt men who sought and held it, not by the nature of its duties. There were some dictators of sound principles, and some emperors as well.

***

Last night, I watched the documentary Park Avenue, which is about the wealth gap in America and the political landscape that has made it so entrenched. I'm not especially politically aware (something I'm working on), so it was shocking to see just how bad things are. The 400 richest Americans control as much wealth as 50% of the country, 150 million people.

For a long time, I've thought this was just the way our system worked: campaigning was expensive, so businesses and wealthy individuals took advantage of this to offer contributions in exchange for laws that further entrenched their wealth.

What I didn't know was that in 1971, soon-to-be Supreme Court Justice Lewis F. Powell wrote a letter to the US Chamber of Commerce, a call-to-arms to US businesses to take a more active role in shaping policy. This was in response to the sweeping political setbacks that had been experienced by corporations in the 60s and early 70s. They heeded the call, and corporate lobbying began to take on the shape it has today.

Thus, our current system of government-by-corporation was not the result of a broken system, but was directly pursued by the corporations themselves in response to a perceived threat to their power.

The result has been the shrinking of the middle class, a huge growth in the income gap, and a polarization of American society between the extremely wealthy and the extremely poor.

To be wealthy in this country is to benefit from corrupt politics and to be a part of a system that oppresses the American people. Or so we have come to believe.

item.title: The World is What You Make It, So Make It Good
item.description:
Choose to be optimistic. It feels better. - His Holiness the Fourteenth Dalai Lama

After class last week, one of my students and I got into a conversation on different approaches to academics. He made an observation that 'truly smart people' have a particular way to thinking, clearly separating himself from that category. I asked him why he didn't include himself in that grouping. He had no answer. He just sort of assumed 'geniuses' were everyone else.

Do you think that belief affected the way that he approached his schoolwork, what sorts of activities he did, or what future he envisioned for himself?

Why not believe he was up there with the 'smart kids'? He himself said he had a solid GPA and did well in school.

***

One of the key tenets of the Warrior Spirit, something essential to living courageously, is the ability to decide how you see the world and how you react to it.

The necessity of questioning the default perspective has always been emphasized by all sorts of inspirational leaders from Buddha to Chris Guillebeau. The point is that you can choose how you see and respond to the world, so you might as well choose an empowering view.

I've always been shocked at how differently the wealthy view money compared to the rest of society. I was first introduced to this in the book, Rich Dad, Poor Dad. The author, Robert Kiyosaki, explains the strange dichotomy between how his working-class father talked about money (or didn't talk) and how his mentor, a wealthy real-estate owner, did. It was as if they lived in two different worlds, with different rules for how money operated.

This book taught me that perspective matters because it changes how we relate to life, how we act, and even what we think is possible. Choosing an empowering perspective can be the difference between floundering and flourishing.

item.title: How to Face Your Inner Demons to Get Unstuck
item.description:
Yesterday, I brought up the reality that we all have troubling questions we'd rather not deal with in our lives, demons that give us excuses to be complacent or hold ourselves back. To answer them is to face our own insecurities and weaknesses. Today, I'm going to dissect those demons so we can vanquish them and pursue our heroic destiny.

Many of these hard questions involve questioning the investment. Some examples:

  • "Am I really happy in this relationship?" -- If the answer is no, it would mean ending a long-term emotional, time, and material investment. If we know the answer will be 'no,' we may avoid asking the question at all.
  • "Why do I stay at a job I hate?" -- The answer to this question often reveals perceived character flaws, things we'd rather not believe about ourselves. Maybe we believe we aren't qualified for anything better, or we think quitting would make us look bad.

People are reluctant to break up long-term relationships because they’ve already invested so much in them, or they are afraid to quit a job because they worked so hard to get it in the first place.

A Choose-Your-Own-Reality Adventure

Why can't we just see an obvious answer, internalize it, and act on it?

The best explanation comes from a psychological theory called cognitive dissonance, which just sounds uncomfortable. It posits that humans have a natural inclination to seek consistency in our lives and actions. If we detect an inconsistency, we feel cognitive stress, which can manifest in a variety of ways from general anxiety up to psychosomatic disorders. Naturally, we will work to eliminate it, even if that means changing our beliefs (which is what the demons of mediocrity want). If we are successful, we can avoid the stress, but some things cannot be hidden, so even if we refuse to acknowledge them consciously, we still know there is an inconsistency.

The classic illustration of this is Aesop's fable, "The Fox and the Grapes":

item.title: Investing in Yourself
item.description:
You experience a windfall and suddenly, your bank account is $1000 fatter. It's not a ton of money, but it's enough to give you some breathing room in the next month or so.

So what do you do with it?

  • Do you pay off some of your student debt?
  • Do you take a trip to India?
  • Do you buy a new dress?
  • Do you learn how to program?

Many of us would spend our money on things we want to fill a need or something we want to consume.

But what if our default mode of spending was to invest in ourselves. Instead of having money leak out of the system, keep it in a cycle to generate more and more. Find ways to convert cash into personal capital. Use that money to make yourself more valuable or increase your ability to generate value.

item.title: If You Have to Cross a Moral Swamp, a Map is Always a Good Idea
item.description: The e-mail I sent out this past weekend was about developing an awareness of the way we construct our morality and whether it restricts or enables us. In a nutshell: A morality basically tells us how we should behave to be happy/good people Moralities can be stated in two ways: To be good, you must not-do/avoid/exclude X. To be good, you must do/include/experience Y. While on the surface, the end result may be the same, the first morality leads to a sense of constant wariness, while the other leads to a stance of accepting life's opportunities.

item.title: Meditating When You Don't Have the Time
item.description: I was at the end of a particularly difficult workout, but I was confident because the final movement was one that I was especially good at: muscle-ups. I ran over to the rings, jumped up and ripped out a single rep. I went for my second--and failed. I tried again--and failed. The clock was running out, so I didn't waste time with chalking my hands, collecting myself, or even setting my grip correctly.

item.title: The Entrepreneurial Benefits of Healthy Living
item.description: I've noticed an interesting trend among ambitious businesspeople: a tendency to neglect their health. They seem to think that they can get away with treating their bodies poorly. In the pursuit of success, they end up pulling all-nighter after all-nighter, eating cheap, quick junk food to get back to work as soon as possible, drinking tons of coffee, and spending hours hunched over the keyboard. I've been in those kinds of situations, and I admire their dedication, but I've also come to learn that a weak body leads to a weak mind.

item.title: 5 Ways to Boost Your Courage Right Now!
item.description: Courage is a valuable commodity. Under various guises--moxie, confidence, spunk, gusto--you can turn a shaky idea into a winning proposition, or go from a wallflower to the life of the party. We crave just the FEELING of courage, even if it's only temporary and hollow, and have created a societal ritual around 'liquid courage' and partying to chase that feeling. Obviously, it's better to cultivate a more lasting kind of courage, but sometimes you just need a quick boost.

item.title: Recovering from the Boulder Flood
item.description: There isn't a blog post for today because coping with the displacement caused by the Boulder floods has prevented me from finding the time to write. I did my best with the posts in the last week, but it finally caught up with me. I do want to express how grateful I am to have such amazing friends, people who were willing to take us in on a moment's notice. A friend picked us up around 11pm in his car during the height of the flood on Wednesday night, after we'd been evacuated.

item.title: You May Be Illiterate
item.description:
Could you imagine turning in a resume that listed, "Can read and write," as one of your notable skills? The idea is laughable, but at one point in history, that was a huge accomplishment and alone could secure you a job far above your station.

Back in the day, by which I mean the early Middle Ages, if you weren't born into the nobility, there were few ways to move up in the world. Military service was one option, but only worked in some places and times. Trade and mercantilism was another, but it required at least some capital to get started.

One of the most reliable ways was to learn how to read and write, to become literate. It was a skill that was in extremely high demand--it was necessary for the conduct of the state and trade--and it was somewhat rare. Those who could convey, prepare, and understand written instructions were entrusted with important information and tasks and granted access to a world of continued learning.

Eventually, literacy became more or less universal. There were those who were more and less literate, but in general, anyone could read a book and write a letter, so you needed something more in order to be of value to those shaping society (or to shape it yourself).

Then came the age of computing (there were probably some other steps in there) and a thing arose called computer literacy. This involved being able to interact with a computer. The computer literate were not necessarily programmers, but they could operate a program and knew how to type.

Being computer literate opened up a lot of opportunities for you. Companies needed operators and you had a good chance of getting a job even if you weren't actually knowledgeable in the company's particular field. Just as a lowly, but literate, peasant might get a job as a merchant's bookkeeper, a kid who could troubleshoot Microsoft Office might work for a local bank without any financial expertise.

Lately, computer literacy has gone the way of word literacy: it has become universal and therefore taken for granted. Computer literacy is expected.

item.title: Is the Environment Broken, or are You?
item.description: From one perspective, our world is broken. The ecosystem is collapsing, the majority of humans live isolated from nature, our society pushes unhealthy foods and inactivity, and it encourages immaturity while punishing us for impulsiveness. Proponents of this belief think, "If only the world matched the one that was best for us, we would all be healthy, fit, happy, and productive. If only the world were set up to encourage human potential, we wouldn't be so frustrated.

item.title: Are you a Doer, or a Dreamer?
item.description: I recently came across this article on Cracked (warning, it is quite inflammatory and contains a lot of strong language, as well as some offensive videos). As the name implies, it is a criticism of people's unwillingness to admit the reality of how the world works. It's targeted at my generation: the Millennials, which has been characterized by a sense of entitlement, aloofness, and a rejection of traditional notions of consumption and wealth (because we're poor, we've made wealth into a sin).

item.title: Are You Trying to Finish Before You Start?
item.description: I don't know what writers do to be great. All I know is that they write. So I write. And that's all I do, for now. I'm sure every situation is different. I'm sure each person has a different path. I can't just copy the lifestyle or habits of one writer or another. I have to make my own path. The only thing they share is that they write. Each of them creates.

item.title: What is Enough for You?
item.description: If you could boil your day down to one or two things, what would they be? Yesterday, Anna and I met a father and husband in Boulder on a very unfortunate errand: bailing his 22-year-old son out of jail. He shared all sorts of stories about his life, his long marriage, and his career. He had spent time as a developer for schools, then as a contractor, but his real passion, he said, was restoring antique furniture.
