item.title: The Hard Questions
item.description:
He hated his job. The sterile thin air that assaulted him as soon as he walked into his office made him sick, and he was on edge until the minute he finally went home. He couldn’t stand his boss, didn’t have any friends among his co-workers, and found his job tedious. It was even affecting his life outside of work: it took him hours to unwind and he winced every time his phone chimed.

His wife knew how bad it was for him, but the one time she had brought it up, he refused to talk about it, instead picking a fight. It wasn’t worth the anger, she decided, but she couldn’t stand watching him suffer.

One day, he came home in a rage, railing against his incompetent boss and some problem his wife couldn’t follow. She calmed him down, but then he just beat up on himself for not being able to handle the situation.

Finally, exasperated, she asked, “Why do you stay? Why do you put yourself through this?”

The automatic answer that almost escaped his lips was, “For us! I do this so we can live a comfortable life!” But he knew that wasn’t the real reason.

A part of him knew the real answers. They had to do with winning his father’s respect, with his fear of starting over, with the fact that his sense of identity was tied up with his work. He knew the real reasons had nothing to do with ‘being a good partner’ or ‘supporting his family’. The real reasons were all things he didn’t want to believe were true about himself.

So he never asked himself the hard questions that would bring the real reasons to light.

It was easier to suffer, he decided, than to admit he had made a mistake.

item.title: 3 Reasons You Shouldn't Make Your Own Decisions
item.description:
I was recently looking for a good meal replacement option to make sure I get enough calories and protein on days when I don't have the time to prepare a good meal. While this may seem like a non-issue, I've made a commitment to only eating whole foods, so it's a bit trickier than it seems. I know how to make this decision, because I've done it before and I'm certainly qualified, as a person who knows what's best for himself and as a trainer with a lot of experience dealing with nutrition. Yet, despite all that, my first inclination was to ask around with my trainer buddies, to check Paleo/Primal blogs, and to put the question to Twitter.

Even with the knowledge that I would make the best decision for myself without any input, I still wanted someone else to make the decision for me.

Because I'm the kind of person that questions my thinking process (in case you haven't picked up on that by now), I wanted to figure out why I felt the need to ask around. After all, I have rarely asked for input on what I should be doing for my own training. Ask 50 trainers what you should be doing and you'll get 50 different answers; it's really something you need to decide for yourself. Once you've done that, then find a trainer who can help you reach that goal. I find it's better to make my own decisions and my own mistakes.

I'm not saying outside input isn't valuable. When you want to learn something, definitely seek out qualified teachers. I saw that Gold Medal Bodies was teaching a lot of people to do previously unattainable gymnastics skills, so I got one of their programs. But when you're making a decision, you already have all the information you need, and you know yourself well enough to know what's good for you, then asking for additional input is just pushing it off.

So, why was I hesitating and looking for outside opinions? I came up with a few answers.

item.title: Insecurity, the Root of All Evil
item.description: A short post, tracing the development of an idea. I've been struggling a lot with patience lately. Patience for myself and for others. I'm normally a really patient person, so I've been trying to figure out why I've been feeling so impatient lately. If I look at the way things have been going, I'd have to say that the biggest change is a constant sense of insecurity regarding my financial life.

item.title: 6 Ways Accepting Your Weaknesses Can Empower You
item.description:
One of the quirks of having subjective conscious experience (aka, self-awareness) is that we have a very different perspective on ourselves than we do on other people. For example, attribution bias tells us that we tend to assume other peoples' actions are the result of their character more than their circumstances, while we openly acknowledge that we are affected by circumstances when it suits us. For example, if we see someone else lie to avoid a fine, we would tend to judge them as generally dishonest. If we do the same thing, we would cite our tight finances and tell ourselves that normally we're honest, law-abiding citizens.

However, this can create some interesting conflicts as well. We may assume we're stronger or more reliable than we really are, or that we will be happy in a situation that won't really make us happy. Maybe the idea of living in New York excites you, but you know that you hate cars and crowds.

Basically, we don’t like to admit that we are as flawed as other people, but if we are to be honest about who we are, if we are to live with integrity, we have to have an accurate view of ourselves, flaws and all.

item.title: An Epic Tale of the Triumph of Will Over Utter Stupidity
item.description:
This article originally appeared on the travel blog I kept while living in Korea.

I had pretty much given up around the 20km mark. My left arch had been cramping since I passed 10km and my feet felt like the road was molten asphalt. I was still moving my feet, but it was more of a shuffle as I gingerly placed each step carefully to avoid even the tiniest jolt to my worn out suspension. I glared resentfully at every pair of cushy, padded, motion-controlled sneakers that cruised by me, their owners floating on a soft cloud of running technology.

I had wondered if running a marathon in my 'barefoot' Merrell Trailgloves was a good idea, but it turned out to be much worse than I had imagined.

This was only my second marathon. The first one I had run in racing flats, and I didn't think there would be too much difference, but it turns out half an inch of foam was the difference between crippling pain and a challenging run.

I had also had a running partner the first time. My dad and I had jogged steadily around the streets of Philly, chatting and sharing observations about the city. Here, in South Korea, I was running alone.

I talked myself into putting one foot in front of the other. Somehow, I made it through the twenties and starting chipping away at kilometer 30, then 31, then 32. Each one seemed longer than the one before. With every...single...step my body wanted to stand still. "Please let me walk, just two steps. I'll do anything!" it begged me. Still I ran.

item.title: Don't Judge the Newbs
item.description:
It saddens me when I see people who have accomplished something judging others who are trying to do the same thing. I see this a lot among trainers, particularly those in unorthodox fitness methods like CrossFit and MovNat. We like to remind other people what they are doing wrong, how they are ignorant, unskilled, or lazy, too focused on strength/flexibility/skill and neglecting our pet trait, how they are clearly too wimpy to do 'real' exercise, etc.

This is only natural. We've put a lot of effort into unlocking the secretes of superpowers, so we want to enjoy the status that gives us. I did it all the time, until I remembered how incompetent I was when I started. But it doesn't actually help anyone.

For example, I was working out with some friends the other day while another gym-goer was loudly, clumsily, doing his own workout. My buddies noticed and snickered, whispering among themselves how what he was doing was both dangerous and inappropriate for his apparent level of fitness.

This wasn't the first time this particular group of friends had indulged in this kind of behavior, so I spoke up. First, I reminded them that the fact that he was out there at all, clearly pushing his limits and trying something new and challenging, was a good thing. Second, every single one of us in that group had gone through a similar phase when we did things that we realized were stupid in retrospect. I tried a lot of weird things, some stupid and some legitimate but misplaced in my training:

item.title: When Life Gets in the Way, What do You Do?
item.description:
Om Gam Ganapataye Namaha -Mantra to Ganesh, Remover of Obstacles

It's the day before, and you've committed to turning over a new leaf. Exercise, productivity, healthy eating, and overflowing compassion, starting tomorrow morning.

But to fit it in, you'll need to get up a bit earlier than usual. No problem, as going to bed early is part of your plan too. Off to bed at 9pm.

But then your neighbor's dog gets loose in the middle of the night and her barking keeps you up for an hour. You wake up groggy when your alarm goes off at 6am.

Life Gets in the Way.

Nevertheless, fueled by the passion of the untried, you make it out for your morning run. It's rough getting started, but once you hit your stride, your pace blows off the early morning cobwebs, and you return home invigorated and encouraged.

At work, you dive right in to your to-do's, rather than checking your e-mail, chatting with your coworkers, and adjusting your seat as usual. By 11am, you're on track to finish your required work so that you can work on that special project of your own that will get you ahead in the company.

Then, Mr. Garfield comes by with a request that you attend an "emergency meeting" right after lunch. Checking your schedule, you figure you can handle the slight delay and still stay on track if you eat at your desk. But, while you're doing that, Sarah comes by and says that she's going out of town tomorrow so she'd like to discuss that important project with you over lunch. There goes your lunch break.

item.title: Listen to Your Intuition: It Could Save Your Life
item.description:
Listen to your intuition. It will tell you everything you need to know. - Anthony J. D'Angelo

He stood out among the other men at the table. He had a sense of practiced confidence about him, and whenever he spoke to the event facilitator--the only woman in the room--his responses seemed too playful, too well-rehearsed, and she laughed as if on cue. When it was his turn to introduce himself to the group, a label popped unsolicited into my head: pickup artist. I filed it to verify in time, and sure enough, he revealed that to be his background. Later during the workshop, he made vague reference to some challenges he was working on, without actually defining them. That voice in my head immediately supplied the details: trouble with commitment. Again, as the class progressed, he revealed that to be exactly his difficulty.

I've never considered myself to be a great judge of people. In college, I'd meet particularly jovial people at parties thinking they were simply really happy, only to be told later that they were obviously drunk. I figured that if I couldn't identify the telltale signs of something so blatant as drunkenness, I should never trust my judgements about people.

item.title: My Solution to the Meaning of Life
item.description: I promised last week to explain the epiphany that led me to make peace with my fear of death. It was based on the realization that I am connected to all of my ancestors. This is going to get deep, so bear with me. So here's the explanation. Zooming out from my personal experience of life, I'm just one iteration of a genetic lineage. In fact, from a particular perspective, the real agent of this experience of existence is not me, Khaled, a human individual alive here and now, but rather the series of individual organisms connected by a genetic history.

item.title: How Committing to Health Teaches you to Stand Out
item.description:
Being in good shape puts you at odds with a lot of society. It denies--or at least minimizes--the value of some of our culture's greatest accomplishments: abundant food, two cars in every driveway, accessible technology, drugs for every ailment. It's generally poor form to question or refuse these blessings of civilization. It angers the other sheep when you start asking questions.

The truth is, our society is not structured to help individuals achieve their greatest potential in health. We've done a very good job of eliminating the stressors that temper our bodies, with the result that our daily lives do not provide the stimulus we need to stay in our best shape. Now, if we want to develop our bodies, we have to go out of our way to do it.

To be healthy, we need to take time out of our life in order to perform extensive and inconvenient maintenance (unless you're one of those people who actually enjoys being active, then maybe you take time out of your life for your job). The alternative is to simply accept what most of the American population does: that chronic disease is inevitable, that the ability to lift and carry more than you weigh is impossible, that hoisting yourself over an object by your own strength is beyond human capability.

Compared to the norm, we have to eat differently, act differently, move differently, sleep differently. To a certain extent, we have to purposefully ostracize ourselves, choose certain friends that can support our habit, and stick out. Other's may respect and even envy health, but that doesn't make it any easier.

Lifestyles of the Rich and Famous

That lifestyle sounds a lot like the one followed by many game-changers and amazingly successful people. From what I've read and researched, starting a successful business that makes a difference requires you to live by a different set of rules. You do things and believe in possibilities that other people don't even consider. You question the status quo about money or the kind of influence you can have. You certainly don't play by the standard rules of go-to-school-get-good-grades-get-a-safe-job.

So essentially, to break out of the status quo in anything, whether it's health, wealth, influence, or comedy, you have to be a radical.

item.title: Why We Avoid Pursuing Our Dreams, and 3 Strategies to Get Motivated
item.description: Nothing ventured, nothing gained. - Anon I marvel at how easy it is for me to do everything except the thing that I dream about: writing a novel. I can blog all day, train, teach fitness and self-defense, promote and market and teach myself Javascript. I make plans and schedules to make these things happen. But for some reason, I have a lot of trouble bringing the same discipline to bear on writing.

item.title: Unlock the Vast Knowledge in Your Ancient DNA
item.description:
I recently discovered a secret store of untapped skill and agility that anyone can use. I was out running on a trail with no shoes on, struggling mightily not to stub my toes on all the rocks and stones. It was mentally exhausting. I'd just finished a novel: God Emperor of Dune. One of the main characters in this book has conscious access to all his ancestor's memories and experiences, encoded in his DNA.

It occurred to me that my body also contains the DNA of all of my ancestors, millions of whom probably spent a lot of time running on rugged trails. In fact, encoded into my DNA and all that has arisen out of it are the instincts of tens of millions (maybe more) organisms, not all human, that spent their entire lives navigating wild, treacherous terrain. Along the way, there must have been some creation of an instinct that helped these creatures manage rocky trails.

And, no matter how my life had progressed, I could not deny that there was in fact some remnant of all that history within me, if only in the way my DNA was constructed. The experience of my ancestors, all the way back to the first proto-life, had created the blueprint for my existence and the framework around which my brain and nervous system were built. It seemed reasonable to think that perhaps there were some useful instincts prebuilt into me.

So I decided to try something. I stopped consciously thinking about where to put my feet. I let go of the need to control my body and leaned forward to pick up speed, forcing my reflexes to direct my actions in order to avoid injury. I trusted my feet and my body's intelligence.

item.title: Mantra for Strength
item.description:
Dwell not upon thy weariness, thy strength shall be according to thy desire. - Arab Proverb
In high school, I decided to become a vegetarian. At first, I was terrified and overwhelmed by the prospect of never eating meat again, but I realized that I didn't have to make such a large commitment at all. All I needed to do was to commit to not eating meat for that particular day.

item.title: How I Turn Fear into Inspiration
item.description:
I've been struggling with my mortality lately. Every few years, I go through periods of my life when I'm hyperaware that I won't be around forever, that this is my only chance to live, and afterwards it will be Eternity of....

I know I'm not unique in this way. All humans know they are going to die, and that awareness has been a driving force in human behavior.

I don't know how other people respond to that reality. I experience a compression of time, and all of a sudden, the decades between now and my death seem utterly trivial, the end as urgent and imminent as the next five minutes. It's really unpleasant.

I do believe in more compassionate explanations of existence than the walking-bag-of-chemical-reactions-becomes-worm-food. The Buddhist and Taoist concepts of universal oneness have a ring of truth to me. Of course, knowing that intellectually is very different from knowing it as a foundational principle of your worldview. Despite everything, I have to admit the dark, hopeless view often seems more real to me, even if it doesn't really make sense based on my beliefs.

This awareness of the imminence of death has been a defining feature of my life since I was very young. It has shaped my worldview and left a strong impression on my sense of values. For a long time, I simply accepted it as a terrible curse, but I eventually realized that I could choose what it meant to me.

So I chose to to interpret it in a way that empowers me and allows me to be happy.

item.title: Why Passion Isn't Enough
item.description: The three great essentials to achieve anything worth while are: Hard work, Stick-to-itiveness, and Common sense. - Thomas Edison No matter how determined you are in weightlifting or any sport, there are limits to your strength that are determined by your training. If you're a beginning lifter, it doesn't matter how badly you want it, you're not lifting 500lbs. No matter how badly you want something or how hard you're willing to try, you can't get by on passion and verve alone.

item.title: How to Find Your Bliss: 3 Questions to Ask Yourself
item.description:
[caption id="attachment_3068" align="alignright" width="300"] Happy dancers at the closing party for WDS21013[/caption]

It's all well and good to tell people to follow their bliss, but how do you find the thing in the first place? If you haven't been following it, it probably wandered off years ago and is lost in someone's backyard howling all alone because you didn't follow it on the epic exploration of the neighborhood that would have led you to meet that cute neighbor you'd fall in love with.

So, anyway, clearly you need to find it so you can follow it on to other adventures.

I spent the last weekend at the World Domination Summit, organized by Chris Guillebeau of The Art of Non-Conformity, where I was inundated by awesomely inspiring speakers and ideas. As the name implies, the World Domination Summit is a gathering of people intent of making a big impact on the world by living fearlessly and pursuing their remarkable dreams in a conventional world.

No one of the talks was specifically about how to find your passion or purpose, but several of the speakers touched on the topic. Three ideas in particular seemed especially actionable.

item.title: Are You Too Stupid to Understand Your Health?
item.description:
Wild lettuce is nearly inedible.

How strange that this food, touted as one of the healthiest icons of a simple, wholesome diet, is not a food humans regularly consumed prior to the advent of agriculture. Wild carrots are woody and fibrous; wild avocados had hardly enough meat to be worth eating; bananas were so full of seeds they would be inedible to modern people.

I recently learned all this watching a video entitled, "Debunking the Paleo Myth" (as usual, I'm way behind the curve). I knew that much of Paleo was based on romantic  but unrealistic notions of Paleolithic cavemen and women living in an edenic utopia chasing mammoth for exercise and eating garden salads, but I had no idea how far off we were.

item.title: 5 Reasons...
item.description: ... you should do it. 1. Because you can Sometimes that's the best reason of all: your potential, and the drive to realize it. You know you can run farther, love more truthfully, lift heavier, earn more, learn more. You know that you can do better. Yet, day after day, you find yourself in the same place you were yesterday, not living up to your potential. This starts to irritate you, but you try to be grateful for what you have.

item.title: 3 Unexpected Benefits of Natural Movement
item.description:
When I started training with natural movements, as opposed to the contrived, isolated, and repetitive movements that used to make up the bulk of my training program, I was mainly interested in the obvious benefits: catlike reflexes, amazing strength, awe-inspiring toughness, and ninja skills.

Mostly, I was focused on the physical benefits.

But I discovered after training this way for a while that it was changing me in other ways, too. I started to relate to my body differently than I had before, even during my years training CrossFit. Instead of feeling constantly inadequate, always being a step behind where I needed to be, I started to feel capable where I was right now, even as I trained to continue improving.

I've written extensively on the physical and mental benefits of natural movement, and plenty of other people have as well, so I just wanted to share some of the less obvious benefits I've found from my training.

item.title: The Smiling Swordsman
item.description:
We once fought together for an ideal with our swords. It wasn't for power or for glory, but to create a peaceful world where people could live without fear. And, if you should forget about that, then what did we fight the revolution for? - Himura Kenshin, Rurouni Kenshin Anime Series

My girlfriend recently introduced me to an anime series called Rurouni Kenshin, about a young man name Himura Kenshin who was an assassin during the Meiji Restoration, a massive revolution in 19th century Japan. The Meiji Restoration's greatest effect was the transference of political power from the militaristic, samurai-controlled Tokagawa Shogunate, which had ruled for 200 years, back to the emperor and his ministers. It also marked the start of modernization, both technologically and socially.

(I want to take a moment to express how lucky and grateful I am to have a girlfriend who insists I watch anime series).

Kenshin was renown as the greatest assassin during the revolution, but the show is actually about him trying to renounce his bloody past and help Japan solidify its new peace. In one episode, his friend points out that Kenshin, of all people, feels the most anger towards the new government because he fought so hard to bring it into existence, only to find it just as exploitative and full of corruption. However, unlike many other characters in the series, Kenshin doesn't see this as justification for continued strife and fighting. Even with the corruption of the new government, he would rather do what he can to ease the lives of everyday people than support another bloody revolution.

He is able to look past his personal feelings and the short-sighted agendas of those he deals with to see the effects on the people of Japan. There is sometimes an air of resignation about him--he must accept the lesser of two evils to preserve peace--but he also carries a lot of hope and faith in the innate goodness of humanity.

Kenshin's character is very interesting for a number of reasons, but the thing that inspires me the most is how he tries to enjoy the little moments of every day. He is usually seen smiling, playing with children, making silly jokes, and generally enjoying life. When a villain shows up with the intention of taking advantage of the weak or causing mayhem, Kenshin puts them in their place very quickly, but for the most part, he tries to appreciate his new life and friends.

Kenshin epitomizes the Warrior Spirit, combining a deep and ruthless concern for the well-being of others with a determination to experience life as joyful.

In the series, there are many characters who respond to the results of revolution much differently, stubbornly fixating on something that upsets them. They may have good intentions, but more often than not, they end up as villains. Their anger and frustration drive them to acts of violence that hurt others or threaten a return to a state of war.

We Create a World to be Bitter In

I sometimes worry about crossing that line. I see a lot to be upset about in the world.

item.title: Choosing Hope
item.description: Wandering the bookstore, I am always amazed at the wide variety of interests and ideas humans cultivate and share. There are people who spend months or years working on books about what I consider trivial topics and stories about everything under the sun. I feel amazed at the power of the human spirit and our many stories, the sheer richness of our culture and civilization. This contrasts strongly with a general misanthropy I've noticed among some of my communities, particularly the local food and paleo/ancestral health communities.

item.title: In the Barefootsteps of Erwan Le Corre
item.description: Boulder's magic strikes again. I was out for a barefoot run last week and decided to explore a new trail. I was getting the usual stares, when one woman held my gaze. I smiled politely, and she did too, but she didn't just turn back to her hike. Instead, she yelled, "Another barefooter like me!" I saw shoes, but when I stopped, I realized they were light moccasins. We walked a while together until we reached a side trail where she removed her shoes.

item.title: Your Superhuman Heritage
item.description:
Shoot for the stars and hit the moon. - Anon

We all dream of becoming something more than we are, of surpassing the everyday. We have an urge to outgrow ourselves: be more healthy, more wealthy, more confident.

Sometimes, we act on that, and sometimes we don't, but it's always there, tickling at the back of our minds. "How wonderful it would be to transcend my limitations?"

To me, one of the most chafing limitations has always been where I can go and what my body is capable of. Whenever I watch movies or even cartoons about exceptional warriors, martial artists, and heroes, I am always surprised by how I feel seeing those fancy moves. It's not awe so much as jealousy, a sense that, not only do I want to be able to do that, I believe that I should be able to.

Now, obviously I have to keep in mind that most of these shows and stories are fiction, and most of the moves are performed by stunt doubles with the aid of special effects. But there are exceptional humans out there who are not always Olympic or world champion level: club gymnasts, strongmen and women, marathoners and ultra-runners, powerlifters, traceurs, rocks climbers, dancers, athletes, Shaolin monks, stuntmen. Anyone from any walk of life can become accomplished in any of these feats that transcend what we consider normal for a human being. They may not break any world records, but a 2x bodyweight deadlift is a significant achievement, and puts you in the top range of (modern, industrialized) humans.

But maybe it's not about becoming something more than what we are. Maybe it's about expressing what we already have within us.

item.title: The Most Important Moment of Your Life
item.description: “Excellence is never an accident. It is always the result of high intention, sincere effort, and intelligent execution; it represents the wise choice of many alternatives - choice, not chance, determines your destiny.” - Aristotle Every moment of every day is full of choices. Some choices are trivial and some have life-altering consequences. Laugh or get angry Eat healthy or eat conveniently Read or watch TV Walk or run Play or work Love or hate Marriage or dating Create or consume College or work Write or don't There are No Turning Points I often catch myself thinking that I need some big event to 'turn over a new leaf' or otherwise start living the life I want/being the person I want to be.

item.title: Dangerous but Safe
item.description: Utah's Canyonlands National Park contains some of the most beautiful and harsh landscape in the world, so when I had the chance to bike and camp through it last month, I was excited to explore the terrain away from the campsite. That first evening, I headed up a rocky slope within sight of camp to really experience the landscape up close. When I got back, it turned out I had upset one of the people I was traveling with, who saw my actions as foolishly dangerous, citing the possibility of me slipping or a tumbling rock causing me to fall.

item.title: Distraction and Fascination
item.description:
Nature presents the young with something so much greater than they are; it offers an environment where they can easily contemplate infinity and eternity. - Richard Louv, Last Child in the Woods

Imagine two children. Both are staring wide-eyed at something, utterly entranced, mouths slightly open. Now back up from each kid and add some context: the first is staring at a TV set, and the second is staring at a spider weaving its web.

What is the difference between nature observation and watching TV? Both involve sitting motionless for long periods of time, observing something else, without much interaction on your part beyond the sensory, and letting your mind get carried off.

But one is distracting while one is fascinating, and I think that is an important distinction to make.

In his book, Last Child in the Woods, Richard Louv introduced me to the concept of fascination as that thing a natural setting does to children who have the free time and access to explore it. Fascination is what happens when children

  • build tree houses
  • play in the mud
  • climb trees
  • make crowns out of daisies
  • or just lie in the grass and watch the clouds blow by

item.title: The Other Side of the Register
item.description:
True compassion is true understanding. - Attributed to the Buddha

My worst nightmare is standing behind the checkout counter at the local supermarket. He has been working there every day for 17 years, 8-10 hours. He goes to bed knowing that, upon waking, all he has to look forward to is another day, another week, another month, another year of standing at the same counter, scanning other peoples' stuff, much of it stuff he can't afford. It's not that he's come to enjoy the job, but he has become numb to the quiet panic that pervades every one of his days.

I'm describing an archetype, not an actual person, the life I don't want to lead, but a life I know many people do live. It is a life I cannot comprehend and one I'm terrified of finding myself in. Knowing others who live it makes me uneasy because of the assumptions I have about human potential. I don't know anyone who aspires to being a cashier, and the mindset that can be happy and accept it is one I simply don't understand.

item.title: Practicing Courage Through Movement
item.description: Do one thing everyday that scares you. - Eleanor Roosevelt After practicing movement and martial arts for so long, I sometimes lose track of the reasons I started in the first place. Lately, I've been on a bit of a hiatus, but I was able to get some training time in last weekend. The combination of time off plus the intensity of training reminded me of why I do this in the first place, and, more importantly, why I want to do this every single day.

item.title: Priorities: Matching Reality to Your Values
item.description:
Upon returning from my trip to Utah, I've found myself caught in a whirlwind of activity, trying to catch up with all sorts of projects. This hasn't given me time to act on the important things that are normally part of my routine, nor the amazing insights I gained in the desert of the Canyonlands. That's one reason this post is late. It is a pattern I've noticed in myself before, when I lived in Korea and was trying to establish a match between the life and wanted and the life I ended up living.

Every now and then, it's good to take stock of how closely the life you're actually living matches the life you want to be living. Are the things that are important to you getting their due, or are they just sitting on the back burner, day after day?

I find that stress tends to lead me to give up on my routines and plans with the excuse of surviving or making do.

It's like that saying about putting your head down and plowing through. You don't know (or don't want to know) where you're going, you just need to get through whatever's in front you, as fast as possible, without regard to finesse or tact.

But the problem with doing that is that sometimes you move forward only to look up to find yourself somewhere you didn't mean to go. Then you've got to go back or find another way. You've wasted effort.

Or worse, because you haven't taken the time to plot your course, you end up barreling into another crisis situation, and the only way to deal with that is to do the same thing that got you there in the first place. Then, you become a slave to events, moving in the direction set by each crisis. At first, you are just telling yourself, "I just need to get through this week, then everything will be back on track." But when that week passes, you haven't taken the time to set your course, and it becomes another week or 'getting through,' then another, then another, until you find yourself lost.

item.title: Lifting the Veil
item.description: Yesterday, I was asked the question, "Do you direct your experiences, or allow experiences to happen to you?" I had to pick an answer in the middle somewhere, because while I normally feel that I should take an active role in my life, lately I have felt that I am intended as an instrument for something. When I am doing the 'wrong' thing, my life seems very difficult, like swimming upstream.

item.title: Spreading the Natural Movement Gospel
item.description:
[caption id="attachment_2744" align="aligncenter" width="500"] Monkeybars in Japan are 3D[/caption]

This post is shared with my movement training website. Head over there if you're curious about learning to move with power and grace.

Now that I live in Boulder, I have the great opportunity to share my love of natural, playful, useful movement with the great community of the University of Colorado at Boulder. With its thriving athletics community and the fact that it is the heart of outdoor- and wellness-obsessed Boulder, CU is the perfect place to introduce young athletes to the concept that exercise doesn't have to be a chore.

But first, I have to prove my skills to the head of the fitness department, and while I do this stuff because I want to flow like a wild animal ninja through the woods, I knew I'd have to tone it down a bit to avoid alienating her. On Tuesday, I had my interview. Here is how it went:

I arrived early to make sure I had time to orient myself to the facilities. The head of the department had structured the interview as a 'Snapshot' training session; I would be training one of CU's established trainers, who would be acting as a naive client. We met outside the locker room, I got changed, and we headed up to the massive weight and cardio room that serves the CU student population.

As I walked by rows and rows of weight machines and treadmills, I began to doubt myself. It was clear that the status quo was well-entrenched here. I didn't want to estrange my 'client', who, as a trainer herself, would probably have some very strong opinions about what was legitimate and what was ridiculous.

I had two choices:

 

  1. Follow the program I had drafted, which was a standard weight loss/strength/'firming up' sequence, with some MovNat thrown into the warmup, OR
  2. Really emphasize the natural movement and blow her mind, hoping that she would get it.

I chose the latter.

item.title: The Problem With Money and Helping People
item.description: The problem with charging people for a service is that it limits who is worthy of being helped. I've been in the position of being someone who is really passionate about learning a skill, and would make the perfect student, but who cannot afford something. It never felt fair because it suggests that only rich people can be skilled or learned or whatever. If I believe that people will benefit from learning how to be more in-tune with their bodies, to move with power and grace, then presumably this applies to all people.

item.title: MovNat Guest Post: Accept Frailty to Grow Strong
item.description: I was recently featured on the MovNat blog, talking about how much of a pansy I am (sort of). I thought I'd just share that article for today. One thing they never tell you about barefoot running is how painful it can be. When you step out on a trail for your first totally unshod trek, eager to run wild and free though the forest, you are suddenly struck with an unexpected problem: tiny pebbles.

item.title: Three Kinds of People, Three Kinds of Success. Which are You?
item.description: How do you define your personal success? When asked what you want in life, do you tell people the job you want to do, or the kind of company and environment you want to work for, or the effect you want to have on the world? Yesterday, I was meeting with a mentor to figure out what I needed to do to be successful and happy in Boulder now that I've quit my job, and to understand why I felt the need to quit my job in the first place (oh yeah, Mom and Dad, by the way, I quit my job.

item.title: The Greenwashing of Exercise
item.description: This post is cross-published on my coaching blog, Warrior Spirit Movement. Most mornings, I head out into the mountains, not to hike, but to ramble. I go where my heart leads me, over rocks, up trees, through fields. And when I am on the trail, I move over it in my own way, hopping from rock to rock or crawling along past wary hikers and excited dogs. Moving in these ways has me sprinting, swinging, scrambling, leaping, reaching, and everything but “Hiking.

item.title: How Annoying Your Sister can Help You Achieve Your Dreams
item.description: My new theory on success is based on techniques I developed annoying my sister, applied to the universe (thanks, L). Here is how it works: I say something I want to be right about: Mommy likes me better. She says the opposite, or simply refutes my argument: Nuh uh! I persist: Uh huh! We repeat the process until one of us tires and the other person's perception is accepted as fact.

item.title: The Vikings are Coming! Keep Drawing!
item.description: One of the greatest literary and artistic accomplishments of Western civilization is an illuminated Bible created in medieval Ireland called The Book of Kells. It contains some of the most intricate illustration anywhere, despite the fact that it was created at a time when having your town pillaged by Vikings was a very real threat and Adobe Illustrator was not yet invented. What fascinates me about The Book isn't the beautiful illumination.

item.title: Nature's Not Here For Our Benefit
item.description: I don't go into the mountains to enjoy them or relax or work up a sweat. I go simply to be among them. I have lately picked up the habit of going on morning hikes. I have about an hour before work, so I see how far I can get into the Front Range before I have to turn back. So far, it's been a meditative experience. I leave the house burdened with worries and concerns, stuck inside my head and trapped by my thoughts, and I return feeling lighter, clear-headed, and open.

item.title: The 80/20 Principle in Training
item.description:
[caption id="attachment_2889" align="aligncenter" width="576"] Dunebashing: 80% Play, 20% Sweat[/caption]

This was a concept that I had trouble understanding from my MovNat trainer certification. I have read The 80/20 Principle by Richard Koch, so it was more an issue of understanding how to apply it to physical adaptation than a failure to grasp the concept. This article is what I came up with.

The few things that work fantastically well should be identified, cultivated, nurtured, and multiplied. - Richard Koch, The 80/20 Principle

80% of our results comes from 20% of our efforts.

This is the 80/20 rule in a nutshell. It means that only 20% of our effort is responsible for most of our results.

  • 20% of our clients supply 80% of our income
  • 20% of our work time is when we get 80% of our assignments done
  • We watch 20% of our movie collection 80% of the time

Okay, that last one may not be totally accurate. Perhaps, if you're me, it's more like you watch 10% of your movie collection 90% of the time, but the point is this:

The majority of our results come from a surprisingly small minority of our efforts or resources.

This is good news, because it means we can cut out 80% of the busy work and dedicate more of our time to the 20% that actually makes a difference. Or we can retain 80% of our current results and spend much less time on achieving them.

In training, that means we should focus on the exercises that make the most difference to our health and ability. These would be exercises that trigger a powerful, full-body adaptation response. Heavy strength training would be preferable to isolation biceps curls, for example (sorry biceps curls, I know everyone picks on you).

item.title: Discovering a New Passion in Cooking
item.description:
[caption id="attachment_2882" align="aligncenter" width="574"] Oh yes, I made that. More importantly, I can do it again[/caption]

I've never considered myself a culinary person. I was never very good at picking up my mom's recipes as a kid, and I needed a cookbook and a measuring spoon to prepare grilled cheese (I'm not exaggerating at all).

However, when I became more insistent on healthy eating in college, I had to learn basic cooking technique; if you insist on whole foods, you need to be able to prepare them yourself. This resulted in a lot of stir-fries at first. The only animal I was comfortable handling was fish. I slowly added a simple recipe and a few techniques to my repertoire (mostly via hurried phone calls to my mom, who demonstrated an amazing ability to rescue even my most ill-conceived cooking adventures).

I learned to cook red meat, I learned to braise, I learned to roast and broil and sauté. I learned knife technique and how to poach an egg.

And then, somewhere along the line, I stopped looking up recipes. Instead, I would imagine what I wanted to eat and mentally map out the steps to get there, complete with sequence of ingredients, temperature, cook times, heating techniques, and spices. I had done enough trial and error (the errors stuck the most) that I had created a cooking toolkit.

I didn't realize I had crossed into amateur chefdom until recently, when I was able to have an informed conversation with a French-trained chef about flavor combinations and methods of preparation and ingredient quality. I think that may have been why he hired me.

And then I realized the recipes I was coming up with were getting fairly complex. Whereas before I might have settled on broiling a fish fillet and some chopped vegetables, now I was browning spiced chicken, caramelizing brussel sprouts, braising them for an hour in ale, and then crisping them under the broiler for the last 10 minutes, just because it seemed like it would be tasty that way.

item.title: 5 Stories of A Little Boy in Nature
item.description:
I woke up this morning and sat on the edge of my futon to meditate, A's breathing setting the backdrop for my own deeper, regulated breath. I had finally managed to wake up early enough that the apartment was silent; there were no dogs scrabbling around in the kitchen, and our roommate was still asleep as well. I was determined to make the most of this time when it would be easier to focus.

After sitting, I picked up a book I'd been intending to start for months, Last Child in the Woods. I read a few pages into the first chapter, remembering stories my dad used to tell about exploring the forest just outside town, hunting squirrels with a rifle. The book is about the epidemic of what the author calls, "nature deficit disorder," a condition arising from a severe and notable lack of interaction with the natural world in children.

I tried to think about my own experiences with nature and came up with very little. I had hated leaving my precious computer games and Nintendo as a child, but when I really thought about it, I did spend quite a lot of time outdoors. Some of my strongest memories were formed in the natural world.

item.title: Lessons Learned About Landing a Job in Boulder
item.description:
[caption id="attachment_2868" align="aligncenter" width="332"] A job to let me land safely...can you tell I had trouble with the image for this post?[/caption]

I'm happy to announce that I have finally landed a job in Boulder, which means that I can stay.

As you know, keeping upbeat in the face of difficult prospects has been hard. Especially going into March, which would have been the limit of my savings, I was worried I was going to hit a wall.

Luckily, just as I reached the end of my financial rope, a job came through. Funny how that works.

Of course, now I have the issue of having too many things to do.

In addition to the usual workaday job at the grocery store, I was also given my first tutoring assignment, and landed my first paid freelance magazine article.

Coaching MovNat is still my preferred form of employment, but that hasn't resulted in any paying arrangements. However, I'm still giving it as much attention as I can spare, going around to gyms and studios offering to run workshops and introduce myself to as wide an audience as possible.

My guess is that I will use the consistent job to get established while developing more lucrative opportunities that allow me to work on my own time.

This period of my life is certainly one of the most challenging and uncomfortable, but I can tell it is also fostering a lot of growth. It's the kind of uncomfortable experience that you know is good for you, even if you'd rather not have to go through it. Sort of like exercise (which I guess I'm fairly good at).

Here are a few short lessons I've learned:

item.title: The Underdog
item.description: I am small. I am new to this dog park. I don't have many friends, and my collar is a hand-me-down. I am young, and know little of the ways of the big dogs. I'm not a purebred, that's for sure. I still have a lot of tricks to learn, and I'm not terribly good at the ones I do know. I am an underdog. But if you think you can bark me out of here, you are dead wrong.

item.title: A Seon Templestay in Korea
item.description:
When we get too caught up in the busyness of the world, we lose connection with one another - and ourselves. - Jack Kornfield

[caption id="attachment_2851" align="aligncenter" width="717"] Photo credit: Anna "Rocketpack" Pusack[/caption]

I woke abruptly in a pitch dark cell, wrapped in pre-dawn silence. Suddenly, the distant wooden bell that had woken me rang out again, accompanied by the ghostly chanting of a Korean Seon (Zen) monk whose duty it was to rouse fellow monks, visiting foreigners, and stubborn Korean teenagers. The sounds faded quickly, swallowed by the forests and mountains around us.

It was 4:00am. The world gave no indication that morning was in the schedule. I had come here exactly for the discipline of this simple temple life, but even I found it difficult to rouse myself this early.

The bell and the chanting monk came closer, moving out of the mystical realm into the waking world. It was time to get up.

I folded my blankets, pulled on my jacket, slid out the heavy wooden door of my sleeping cell, and started up the mountain to join the others in a session of Buddhist chanting and meditation.

Stepping into a small, close shrine, I took my place at a meditation cushion. My girlfriend and I had been taught the day before how to do the introductory bows, and we went through them now, knees and backs aching. Soon, everyone had arrived.

A monk rang a clapper and all was silent. Then, as abrupt and distinct as the lone wooden bell, chanting rang out and engulfed the room. We were carried away in its driving, insistent rhythm that thrummed like a force of nature through our bodies.

The spirit of Buddha awoke within us like a lotus, coaxed from sleep by the relentless, comforting chants.

So began my templestay at Golgulsa Temple in Gyeong-ju, South Korea.

item.title: No Egos Beyond This Point
item.description:
If your practice is good, you may become proud of it. What you do is good, but something more is added to it. Pride is extra. Right effort is to get rid of something extra. - Shunryu Suzuki

The theme of this year is definitely humility.

I have this annoying habit of questioning authority in all its forms, even when it's authority I normally support, i.e., my MovNat trainers at my recent certification.

The workshop was well run and everyone got a lot out of it, but at one point, I found something to pick on and made a big deal out of nothing. I realize, looking back, that I had primed myself for a confrontation by the attitude I brought in to the certification, which was one of proving myself rather than learning something.

After it all went down, I was pretty upset, not so much with the trainers, who handled it very professionally, but with myself for being bothered and for feeling the need to do or say anything. After all, it wasn't my workshop, nor was it my responsibility. I spent a troubled evening losing sleep and trying to figure out what it was inside me that was causing me so much anxiety.

I eventually figured out it was the desire to prove myself rather than let go and simply learn. I reached out to my sister for advice, and she wisely suggested I make a distinction between observation (learning) and judging (reacting). So, the next morning, after a sincere and humbling apology (damage control), I made a point of simply observing and withholding judgement for the remaining three days.

Needless to say, I learned a lot more that way than with my original approach.

item.title: The Little Chieftain; Are You Waiting for Permission to Live?
item.description:
The once was a tribe of people living in an ancient land. They chose from among their number one to lead them, a chief, who was the most skilled in hunting, diplomacy, and wisdom. He or she was to be a beacon for the tribe, a person to inspire a sense of belonging and security.

One year, as the current chief was dying, there were two candidates to replace her. Both boys were truly skilled in the art of warriorship, and both possessed wisdom beyond their years. They were of the same age, at the cusp of manhood, but one still acted like a little boy. He felt like someone or something had to give him permission to be a man. The other acted as if manhood were already his. He took an air of fatherhood around the children and acted like an equal among the elders.

Despite this, the tribe still had trouble deciding, for both boys were exceptionally skilled and passed all the tests of intellect and insight. After a long day being interviewed, the two of them found themselves alone in the chief's room, the elders having retired to discuss. Sitting in the back of the room were the chieftain's robes and headdress.

As boys are wont to do, they grew curious about that which is forbidden them, and finally they decided try on these magical garments. They had been fashioned for an adult, and clearly would fit neither boy, but they wanted to feel what it would be like.

The first boy threw the robe around his scrawny shoulders and lowered the headdress over his brow. His friend only barely managed to stifle a laugh, and truly the boy in the robes felt strange and uncomfortable. He hunched, as if trying to get away from the feathers that adorned his head. They robes didn't fit, physically or otherwise, but he assumed they would feel more comfortable over time, just as his bow had felt awkward until he had taken it on several hunts. He knew that if he were selected, the tribe's permission would give him the certainty he needed to fill the outfit.

Now the other boy donned the garb, and the large robe slipped down his narrow shoulders. But when the first boy looked on his friend smiling and standing tall under the too-large headdress, he saw that this boy wore the cloak and feathers like they were already his. The way he stood, the way he bore them proudly instead of uncertainly, said that he could already see himself as the chief. Perhaps there were skills to be learned, but this boy was not shy of being called chief and being looked to for guidance. Though the garb didn't fit physically, it seemed to belong to this boy.

The first boy told his friend what he saw and he left the room to tell the elders he was withdrawing. And the little chief who had always been a chief led his tribe on to many great victories.

***

Having arrived in Boulder, I set about trying to establish a life here. Income was (is) hard to come by. I live in a shared apartment, and I've applied to a lot of part-time jobs to try to get things started.

It's pretty scary sometimes.

Then I met a guy, not even my age, who goes to work in a suit and tie, who owns his own condo, and who doesn't just work because he needs a bit of money as he sets up for his next step, but who is a contributing member of society.

I know I am quite mature in regards to psychology, emotional intelligence, and personal integrity, but in terms of my material prosperity, I still envision my life like a student, someone dependent, in transition.

item.title: A World Unto Yourself: The Ecological Nature of Health
item.description:
Know thyself. - Plato

The human body is a wonderfully complex organism. It puts even the most refined watches to shame in terms of the technical precision that enables it to run, and the ingeniousness with which the human (or any other) body is put together continues to astound doctors, philosophers, psychologists, biologists, theologians, and anyone else who witnesses it.

And yet, despite this deep complexity, we often treat our bodies like simple machines. We believe that we can change one thing without accounting for anything else. This comes across in the many fitness fads of bulking up vs. cutting vs. toning, as if our bodies were cars that could be tweaked and fine-tuned. All you need to do is lift heavier, or follow this one routine, or eat this one superfood, or take cold showers.

item.title: Live What You Preach: Maintaining Faith in my Move to Boulder
item.description:
[caption id="attachment_2811" align="aligncenter" width="500"] Credit: Anna Pusack[/caption]

“When you have come to the edge Of all light that you know And are about to drop off into the darkness Of the unknown, Faith is knowing One of two things will happen: There will be something solid to stand on or You will be taught to fly.” - Patrick Overton

I'll be honest: while I write about taking big risks and facing your fears, I have always had the luxury of financial security from my parents. After college, I moved home and worked from there, and in 2011, I moved to Korea as a contracted ESL teacher, a job that came with housing and a steady paycheck.

That doesn't make what I write about any less valid. I've heard from many of my readers how they have taken my words to heart and faced up to challenges in their lives, making changes for the better despite great fear and risk.

But perhaps having never faced that particular rite of passage that is moving out on my own, my philosophy is missing the certainty of one who has been tempered by experience.

Well, now I'm being called to live up to my own advice in a very urgent way. Having moved to Boulder at the end of January with no more than a light bank account, I've been working frantically to find or make work for myself. Staring at a shrinking bank statement really drives home whether or not I have faith in what I write about.

Here is what I've learned so far:

item.title: Less is More in Health: Minimalist Hygiene Tips
item.description:
“As you simplify your life, the laws of the universe will be simpler; solitude will not be solitude, poverty will not be poverty, nor weakness weakness.” - Henry David Thoreau

It's no surprise to followers of ancestral living that, when it comes to health, less is often more. Of course, we mean less of the right things:

  • Less additives
  • Less sugar
  • Less processing
  • Less cushioning in our shoes
  • Less furniture (remember the evils of sitting)

Generally, we like living as close to our natural state as possible.

I wrote a post a while back about about my strange health habits that have made a big difference for me, and I realized that many of them also helped me save money. I used to have quite a lot of hygiene products in my never-ending attempts to maintain a healthy body. These included:

  • handsoap
  • bodywash
  • shampoo
  • conditioner
  • shaving cream
  • aftershave
  • shaving razors and refills
  • laundry detergent
  • dishwashing detergent
  • Chemical deodorant
  • Contact solution
  • etc.

I realized that I was spending a lot of money on products that are basically unnecessary. Even eco-friendly products often have a lot of unnecessary stuff in them, and of course the 'green' label justifies charging more for them. It didn't make sense to me that humans needed such complex chemicals just to stay clean. So I started learning about alternatives and DIY-recipes. I've since reduced my products down to the following:

item.title: Empower Yourself Through Humility
item.description:
Humility reminds us that we are human. It reminds us not to overestimate our abilities, not to get sloppy and lazy, to always be present and give our best effort.

Humility reminds us that the big tasks, the ones that matter, really are difficult, even for such amazing warriors as ourselves. Remembering this, we will remain focused, taking the task seriously and bringing to it the attention it deserves.

Humility says, "I could mess this up, so I will make sure I don't."

Only the fool forgoes humility for hubris. If he is talented, he will get far, but eventually, the task at hand will be bigger than he can handle casually. Eventually, it will require an acceptance of the need for help, either from other people or deeper wells of energy and focus.

***

Recently, I've adopted the habit of bowing upon waking and just before bed. Bowing is an interesting form of devotion because it is an expression of humility. You are honoring whatever you bow to by being humble before it.

To me, that suggests an acknowledgement of how much we rely on certain things and how important mindfulness is. I recite certain gratitudes when I bow. For example, I give thanks for the opportunity to rest and recover at night, and then I bow. This expresses the acknowledgement that I don't necessarily have the right to peaceful rest -- many people don't get it. I am thankful for it, but also humbled by it, since I depend on it to function.

item.title: How to Get Others to Inspire Your Growth
item.description:
Standing on the broken edge of the Earth that had been thrust up out of the ground thousands of years ago but still as jagged as ever, I gazed across a chasm occluded by falling snow. On the other side was wild mountain forest, filling in the gaps of another chunk of tectonic rock that had been forcibly pried into the sky by the Rockies beyond.

I could think of no better way to spend a Saturday afternoon. This was the life I wanted for myself.

But if I were honest, I would never have brought myself out here on my own. I owed the motivation for this trip to a new friend, and to the community that makes a spur-of-the-moment jaunt into the mountains a reasonable possibility.

Left to my own devices, I would have been at home, safely tucked into my comfort zone, watching the snow fall and wondering if I was really living up to the Boulder lifestyle.

item.title: Change the World from the Inside Out
item.description:
[caption id="attachment_2782" align="aligncenter" width="576"] Meditation is time well-spent; it tempers the soul to face the challenges of the world. Credit: Anna Pusack[/caption]

“Peace comes from within. Do not seek it without.” - Buddha

In high school, I entertained lofty notions of fixing many of the world’s problems. However, I did not feel up to the task. Despite my ambitions, I felt fearful and weak. Whenever I contemplated tackling the big issues, I saw them as far beyond my capabilities. But instead of focusing on increasing my capabilities, I instead tried to think of ways I could tackle these challenges with just what I had at the time.

The result was that I felt constantly overwhelmed. In high school, I spent most of my time despairing how ineffective I was. In college, I did what a lot of people do: I stopped caring and focused on enjoying my life, often through distraction.

Luckily, I received a Warrior calling that brought my life back on track. As I started training my body, and developing emotional and mental strength, I found myself becoming more confident and outgoing. Problems that had overwhelmed me no longer did, and I felt a noticeable increase in my sense of effectiveness. My grades improved, even as I took on more extra-curricular activities.

A New Path for a Wimpy Kid

Picking up on this, I looked for other areas in which I could cultivate inner strength. After college, I returned to my study of self-defense and systematically improved my people skills. The following year, I set my sights on living and working in Korea to foster the ability to live independantly. I took on the challenges of expanding this blog and writing a book.

All this was done with an eye towards increasing my sense of empowerment and convincing myself that my dreams were within my grasp and, perhaps more importantly, worth pursuing.

The result has been a tremendous increase in my strength of purpose and my faith in my ability to effect positive change in the world.

item.title: A Story of Humanity and Civilization
item.description: Sometimes I can't sleep. My mind whirls around, jumping from one thing to the next, sometimes so fast it scares me and I have to open my eyes to stare at the blackness of my room. Viewing the world in distinct categories, I end up feeling overwhelmed because there is too much to keep track of. When my mind finally relaxes, the artificial distinctions I use to categorize the world dissolve, and it is all revealed to be One.

item.title: I'm Moving to Boulder
item.description: [caption id="attachment_2768" align="aligncenter" width="576"]Flatirons, here I come[/caption] “The first step towards getting somewhere is to decide that you are not going to stay where you are.” - Anon By the time you read this, I will have landed in Boulder, CO, my new home for the foreseeable future. That's a little scary to say now. I only decided to move here 30 days ago. The road that brought me here was sort of a surprise, like a forest path you don't see until you're right on top of it.

item.title: How Moving Well Can Make You Confident and Popular
item.description:
[caption id="attachment_2744" align="aligncenter" width="500"] Monkeybars in Japan are 3D[/caption]

Last week, I was doing some research for an article I'm writing on play as exercise, and I needed a photograph of a playground. Of course, that meant I had to test out the playground, which got me thinking on how central the playground was in my daily life when I was a kid.

Movement as a Rite of Passage

The American School of Dubai, where I went to elementary school, had a pretty awesome playground. The front consisted of three corridors of hanging traverse: there was a line of monkey bars flanked on both sides by lines of hanging rings. The rings on the left were short and closely spaced, while those on the right had much larger spaces.

I remember aspiring to complete the full set on the right side, like all the big kids. Every day, before school, at recess, and after school, I would practice swinging from the rings. Some days I would just do the short rings, to build confidence, but I usually gave the long rings a shot. I would patiently wait my turn in line with the big kids, enduring sneers and ridicule (I don't honestly remember), until I came to the front of the line.

My heart would catch. After waiting in line for agonizing minutes, would I now waste all of that by falling to the sand in failure after one measly swing?

item.title: The Warrior Mindset Part 3: The Warrior’s Obligation
item.description:
"They shall beat their swords into plowshares and their spears into pruning hooks. Nation will not take up sword against nation, nor will they train for war anymore."
-Isaiah 2:4

This is a guest post from Shawn Rhodes, founder of Shoshin Consulting. After growing up in the mountains training in martial arts and eastern philosophy, he followed his own warrior’s calling and joined the U.S. Marines. There, he accompanied infantry Marines through two tours in Iraq, documenting their trials and victories for international news outlets like CNN and TIME. While living and fighting alongside this tribe of modern-day warriors, he discovered the link between the warrior’s path and mastery in life. He returned to the U.S. with the passion to share a vision of what humans are capable of when they embrace their own inner warrior and return to a mindset where all paths are possible.

***

This is the third in a three-part series on The Warrior's Path. Each installment will explore the evolution of the warrior mindset. Rooted in ancient methods warriors followed for thousands of years, adopting this mindset can help anyone to regain balance, direction, and control of their health, success, and life.

In the first part of this series, I showed readers how past and present-day warriors learn to shift their mindsets, allowing them to transform the problems they face into challenges of responsibility for the quality of their lives. In part two, readers stepped into the mindset of a mature and experienced warrior, a person who is confident in their abilities and no longer feels the need to prove themselves. As a result of this mindset, they see experiences in their lives as opportunities for growth as warriors and human beings.

What is the next stage in a warrior’s development?

To answer this, it would be helpful to examine the roles that warriors throughout history have played when they - as a culture - existed in peacetime. It makes sense that skillful warriors would eventually work themselves out of a job by either death or victory. However, the warrior tradition in human cultures has grown to allow for periods of peace. In fact, some of the most skilled warrior societies were based on achieving internal and external peace. Japanese culture, for instance, gave rise to the renowned Samurai.  The word for ‘warrior’ - bushi  (武士) – is comprised of symbols for ‘a spear being removed or taken away.’

There are very few warriors who experienced and fought in prolonged combat who would choose that lifestyle for themselves and their families. It is a paradox that to achieve peace one must confront war (internally, externally, or both), but it is true. A warriors’ ultimate objective is to bring peace to themselves and their world.

Once a warrior finds a place of peace, their real challenge begins.

item.title: The Warrior Mindset Part 2: Transform Challenges Into Opportunities
item.description:
Shawn Rhodes, founder of Shoshin Consulting, is a traveler, teacher and above all, a lifelong student. After growing up in the mountains training in martial arts and eastern philosophy, he followed his own warrior's calling and joined the U.S. Marines. There, he accompanied infantry Marines through two combat tours in Iraq, documenting their trials and victories for international news outlets like CNN and TIME. While living and fighting alongside this tribe of modern-day warriors, he discovered the link between the warrior's path and mastery in life. He returned to the U.S. with the passion to share a vision of what humans are capable of when they embrace their own inner warrior and return to a mindset where all paths are possible.

***

This is the second in a three-part series on The Warrior's Path. Each installment will explore the evolution of the warrior mindset. Rooted in ancient methods warriors followed for thousands of years, adopting this mindset can help anyone to regain balance, direction, and control of their health, success, and life.

In the first part of this series, readers learned how to use the ancient mindset of the warrior to see life in a new way. Instead of viewing the world as a place that acts upon our lives, we learned everyone has the ability to choose how to process situations. Seeing each problem in life as a challenge to shift our mindset is the first stage of warriorhood.

In the second installment of this series, we will learn the next stage in the evolution of the warrior mindset is turning those challenges into opportunities, and why it’s the supreme form of power.

Unfortunately, many people - especially young men - get stuck in the first stage of a warrior’s development. They’ve learned to see the problems in their lives as challenges, but they make a key mistake that freezes their development: they see each challenge as a threat and a test of their strength. We’ve all seen the chest-puffing and rooster dance from two guys at the bar or on the schoolyard.

The Need to Prove

I’m convinced, after seeing firsthand people spend months trying to kill each other in modern war, that much of the violence in this world comes from people feeling threatened and wanting to protect what they see as ‘theirs‘: their life, their property, their ideologies.

These folks aren’t operating from the mindset of mature warriors; they are approaching their lives like a guard defending a castle, afraid of the walls crumbling at any moment. Without their bravado and one-upmanship, others might discover just how fragile their self-image really is. People frozen in this stage may be extremely skilled fighters, but they rush blindly into battles without examining the playing field for the best - and easiest - ways to win.

In one of the most famous texts outlining the warrior mindset - The Hagakure - its author Yamamoto Tsunemoto likens a skilled warrior on the battlefield to a hawk taking down a single bird in a flock. Experienced warriors focus their minds on a task - or an opponent - and are unconcerned with the opinions of others in the flock or social circle. Instead, they are more concerned with performance than they are with proving their competence. This makes them extremely effective at whatever they set their minds to, whether it’s being a fighter or an artist.

If you are young and still exploring your relationship to your world by comparing your strength against others, the sooner you move past needing to prove yourself, the sooner you can embrace a deeper kind of power.

item.title: The Warrior Mindset Part 1: Turn Problems Into Challenges
item.description:
This is a guest post from Shawn Rhodes, founder of Shoshin Consulting. Shawn is a traveler, teacher and above all, a lifelong student. After growing up in the mountains training in martial arts and eastern philosophy, he followed his own warrior's calling and joined the U.S. Marines. There, he accompanied infantry Marines through two combat tours in Iraq, documenting their trials and victories for international news outlets like CNN and TIME. While living and fighting alongside this tribe of modern-day warriors, he discovered the link between the warrior's path and mastery in life. He returned to the U.S. with the passion to share a vision of what humans are capable of when they embrace their own inner warrior and return to a mindset where all paths are possible.

***

This is the first in a three-part series on The Warrior's Path. Each installment will explore the evolution of the warrior mindset.  Rooted in ancient methods warriors followed for thousands of years, these installments will give readers a glimpse into how traditional and modern warriors see the world.  Adopting this mindset can help anyone regain balance, direction, and control of their health, success, and life.

The traditional role of the fighter - the person who trains from a young age to be skilled in combat - is disappearing. For better or worse, the mindset learned from a lifetime of turning problems to one’s advantage on the battlefield or the boardroom is being lost. Technology is changing the face of war and our world. The traditional warrior's path - years of intense physical training, exposure to the elements, mental exhaustion, moments that burn into memory - is not for everyone. That doesn't mean you can't benefit from the way warriors learn to see themselves and the world, however. I believe this valiant spirit lives inside everyone, and that we can all benefit from learning how to approach the world like a warrior.

A select few still hear the call to embrace warriorhood; not the call to control others with force, but to turn their focus inward to the battlefield of their own lives.

This calling is universal to every place and age. As we allow ourselves to become dependent on external distractions to fill our inner voids, the call to seize control of our destinies and live with a courageous spirit is louder than ever.

So many of us turn to television, alcohol, drugs, and even chronic exercise in the hope it will distract us from our responsibility as human beings and warriors: the mission of the warrior is to discover all they are capable of being.

item.title: Are You as Fit as Your Dog? 5 Ways to Play Fetch
item.description:
We've had a series of intense posts lately, and there are more in the schedule (see below for more on that...and a funny video of me falling in the mud), so here's a much more lighthearted one.

I'm a strong advocate of spontaneous, playful movement as the best way to get exercise. That's why I love MovNat's philosophy. I feel that play is more engaging, gets your mind off the strain of exercising (so you'll do more), and can be shared as social activity.

Lately, I've been undergoing a self-imposed training program for my MovNat Trainer Certification, which has been lonely in the cold winter of New England. This past weekend, I finally got my girlfriend (who will now be referred to as Rocketpack instead of the mysterious, A) to come out with me. Seizing on this opportunity for social play, I came up with a game to make my sprint-esque workout more interesting.

We played a timeless classic, enjoyed not just by humans, but by our furry friends as well.

Yup, we played fetch.

item.title: How to Make a Dream Come True
item.description:
It isn't very often that we get to cross out a big goal in our lives, but that is exactly what I did at the end of November. I'd been dreaming of becoming a MovNat trainer since I heard about the method in 2009. Around April of last year, when MovNat announced they were offering trainer certifications, I finally decided to make this dream a reality. I couldn't afford the certification with what I was making as an ESL teacher; I would have to raise the money by writing and promoting an eBook, which I published in September of 2012.

By November of 2012, I had raised enough from donations for the eBook (as well as a few t-shirt sales) to sign up for my MovNat trainer certification in March 2013.

It was a long road to get there, but the most valuable thing I got out of the whole experience won't be the MCT certification itself. Instead, it is the confidence that I can affect my life without permission from anyone else.

item.title: The Things That Matter
item.description:
It started as a way to live responsibly. Knowing all the suffering and pollution caused by industrial farming and how that impacted my health, I made the commitment to eating organic and supporting local food whenever possible.

To simplify my decision-making, I made up all sorts of rules about what I could and couldn't eat. Soon, adhering to the rules became more important than what the rules were meant to help me accomplish, which was eating in harmony. This harmonious way of eating would naturally give rise to health, but when I ran into the Paleo and Primal communities, health itself took the top priority.

In all the obsession over good vs. bad carbs, optimal post-workout nutrition, and coconut substitutions for everything, I realized my diet had become meaningless. By all accounts, I ate well. My food was high quality and nutritious, but all this was lost on me. I didn't even taste my meals anymore.

I don't know how common this is among Paleo eaters and I hope you will leave comments sharing your experiences. It seems to me that obsessing over the health aspects of Paleo (dangerously easy to do given the mindset of the community) could lead us to forget how to enjoy our food for its own sake.

Eventually, I came to believe that my health doesn't matter, per se. I didn't live to be healthy. I was healthy in order to live well. How I ate needed to be a reflection of that goal.

“I believe that the very purpose of our life is to seek happiness. That is clear." - His Holiness the 14th Dalai Lama

When I realized that, I stopped getting so upset with the dietary rules. Eventually, I was able to reconnect with the enjoyment of my food again.

The thing is, as you get deeper into Paleo, you realize that optimal health requires eating and living sustainably. So, even if your main priority is health, you are forced to aim higher, to prioritize something more general, in order to achieve that. The reality forces a widening of your concerns. If you refuse to see this, you end up chasing your own tail in a never-ended spiral of healthy living.

item.title: The 6 Strangest Health Habits
item.description: That's me hanging on the ledge in the middle of the photo. I will always remember the night I willingly lowered myself into an ice bath as the day I went over the edge and became certifiably weird. Crazy might be a better term for it. Healthy behavior can seem unusual when viewed from the perspective of the mainstream. After all, the very fact that some behavior stands out as "

item.title: Forget the Resolution! Set a Challenge!
item.description:
Resolutions are boring. I resolve to behave better this year, blah, blah, blah... This is a whole new YEAR we're talking about, not just the turn of an hourglass.
