So I've been helping out at the CT Humane Society for a few months now, and have spent a lot of time with really adorable, heartbreakingly cute kitties and puppies that want nothing more than to play and be loved. Yeah, it's rough work, but someone's got to do it.

Anyway, I've learned a lot of important things from these animals, both from their suffering and the little joys they manage to find in life at the shelter. Here are some examples:

item.title: Are You Fed Up Yet?
item.description:
[caption id="attachment_1254" align="alignright" width="300" caption="mdanys on Flickr"][/caption]

“Consult not your fears but your hopes and your dreams. Think not about your frustrations, but about your unfulfilled potential. Concern yourself not with what you tried and failed in, but with what it is still possible for you to do.” - Pope John XXIII

I am fed up with reading about all these ways to make things happen, with making plans and taking false starts. You might recall my response to The 4-Hour Workweek, in which I established a very doable plan that ultimately got sidetracked. All I got out of that experience was a new way to see the world which ought to enable me to live the life I want. It freed me from accepting the normal path and got me to thinking that I can design my own life. But from what I can see I never actually went past designing it.

I have to wonder why.

item.title: What I Fight For
item.description:
[caption id="attachment_1251" align="alignright" width="300" caption="Beverly and Pack on Flickr"][/caption]

“It is the observation here that our cause is the cause of all mankind, and that we are fighting for their liberty in defending our own” - Benjamin Franklin

Throughout history, societies have always gone through cycles of establishment and revolution. The established order, originally meant as liberating, starts to become oppressive in its attempts to institutionalize itself. In turn, revolutionaries rise to oppose the system, to assert individuality and reinstate the balance. Sometimes they fail, sometimes they are incorporated into the existing order, and sometimes they overthrow the current order and establish their own system. We are at a time of revolution, though it is a quiet one.

item.title: Teacher Appreciation
item.description:
[caption id="attachment_1247" align="alignright" width="300" caption="Abhijit Tembhekar on Flickr"][/caption]

Wax on, wax off. - Mr. Miyagi, the Karate Kid (1984)

Warriors are always seeking to grow and learn new things, so it makes sense that we'd have a lot of teachers in our life. As the year comes to a close and I contemplate my card list, I'm realizing that most of the people on it are my teachers and mentors. In the past two years, I've acquired an unusually large number of teachers, of exceptionally good quality, and I realize that all the growth and knowledge I've acquired is largely thanks to their efforts.

item.title: Mythic Warriors: Link
item.description:
[caption id="attachment_1244" align="alignright" width="300" caption="Copyright Nintendo, Inc"][/caption]

A sword wields no strength unless the hand that holds it has courage. You may be destined to become the hero of legend...but your current power would disgrace the proud green of the hero's tunic you wear. You must use your courage to seek power...and find it you must. Only then will you become the hero for whom this world despairs. - Hero's Shade, The Legend of Zelda: Twilight Princess

Clad in a green tunic and wielding the legendary Master Sword, Link is the hero of The Legend of Zelda series of games from Nintendo. Throughout the game's long history, he has faced countless foes ranging from evil wizards to psychotic masks, solved numerous mind-bending puzzles, and repeatedly saved the world from oblivion. All the while managing to get some time in for leisurely fishing, mini-games, favors for random folks, and practicing his various instruments. Variously depicted as a boy or a young man, Link is the possessor of the Triforce of Courage and is perhaps one of the greatest examples of heroism our young video-game addicted selves might have been exposed to. He has all the traits of a true Warrior, and exemplifies the Warrior Spirit.

item.title: "Are you a Writer?"
item.description:
[caption id="attachment_1240" align="alignright" width="225" caption="John Althouse Cohen on Flickr"][/caption]

“Every human being has hundreds of separate people living under his skin. The talent of a writer is his ability to give them their separate names, identities, personalities and have them relate to other characters living with him.” - Mel Brooks

I was standing on the train platform on my way into New York when a young girl standing with her mother looked over and asked me, "Are you a writer?"

I have never been asked this before. Normally, if people see me carrying my journal, they ask if I write, but not if I am myself a 'writer'. But this girl thought I looked like a writer, with my long hair, unshaven beard, and worn leather jacket. Or maybe it was the classically creative look of my Moleskine journal (thank you Moleskine, I will never make fun of your pretentiousness again).

The question left me speechless for a moment. I was almost suspicious, as if the girl had asked me, "Would you like an extra $500?" The first thing you want is to say yes, but it just seems too easy.

item.title: I'm not Broken, and I Don't Need to be Fixed
item.description:
“The human soul, as a part of the movement of life, is endowed with the ability to participate in the uplift, elevation, perfection, and completion.” -Alfred Adler

A consumerist society survives off the needs of its members. Thus, it has an interest in convincing the people that they need a wide variety of things and services, else they risk unhappiness and inadequacy. And what better way to support this kind of information campaign than to train people that they are inherently flawed from birth, destined to always come up short without the gracious help of external products and services, doomed to chronic disease without the newest fad in health foods.

item.title: Right Action, Right Intent
item.description:
[caption id="attachment_1232" align="alignright" width="300" caption="Alice PopKorn on Flickr"][/caption]

"We make sacred pact. I promise teach karate to you, you promise learn. I say, you do, no questions." -Mr. Miyagi, Karate Kid (1984)

My dad has been baking a lot of bread recently, experimenting with different ingredients and developing his own unique style of bread. When I read his cookbook, I found out why. Instead of simply giving him a bread recipe, the author of his book explains what each step is intended to accomplish: the various factors that determine how much flour to use, how long to let the bread rise, why you let the bread rise, and what occurs in the dough during baking. It borders on chemistry, but the result is that my dad has a much better grasp of why each step must be taken, and can make adjustments to get his desired effect. If he wants to get a crispier crust, he knows what to change and how to compensate to avoid ruining his loaves.

item.title: Patience
item.description:
[caption id="attachment_1226" align="alignright" width="300" caption="WasabiDoobie on Flickr"][/caption]

“Genius is only a greater aptitude for patience.” - George-Louis Leclerc de Buffon

Lately, I have had a lot of waiting to do as my plans start to gain momentum. There are long periods during which nothing seems to bear any fruit. Farm to Table went silent for a long time, with almost no new comments or community engagement, leading me to get very discouraged. I was lacking motivation in my workouts and didn't really feel like I was making any progress. My blog seemed to be wallowing in obscurity.

Then, all of sudden things started to move very quickly, and I realized that it was the quiet times when things were starting to move towards a tipping point. I am getting a lot of people reaching out to connect over Farm to Table, there is a new energy in my training, and I am making all sorts of friends while reconnecting with old ones. It's almost more than I can handle.

item.title: A Writer's Struggles as a Blogger
item.description:
[caption id="attachment_1223" align="alignright" width="300" caption="amanky on Flickr"][/caption]

"Blogging is not rocket science, it’s about being yourself, and putting what you have into it." -Unknown

Blogging is both a wonderful and a frustrating experience for a writer. On the one hand, it gives you the opportunity to put your ideas out there with no publishing costs and the freedom to write whatever you want. On the other hand, it leaves all the publicity up to you. It's like a journal that people might actually care about and read, and it creates the possibility of a self-crafted audience. I've come a long way as a blogger, but I still find that I have a lot to learn.

item.title: What is Warrior Spirit?
item.description: The warrior stands defiant, spear in hand, looking over a vast plain. Below him is a world full of challenge and adversity, dangerous enemies and tempting shortcuts. Beyond is a great mountain range, full of promise certainly, but hiding even greater challenges. On the other side...who knows? Hope, transcendence, enlightenment. Or perhaps darker, more sinister rewards hide behind those peaks. All the Warrior knows is that he has decided to scale them, carve a path through the plains and over the mountains, leading the way for others who seek a better life on the other side, guiding them and defending the tribe from the dangers ahead. He knows he may not survive, but he has prepared well and is among the greatest, most capable leaders of his tribe. He is confident and eager to begin.

item.title: E-book Review: A Simple Guide to Eating Well
item.description:
This is a review of an e-book by a fellow blogger that I've followed for years. His blog, Zen to Fitness, is inspired by the idea that health and vitality should not be a struggle. I am not an affiliate marketer for his book; this review is simply me sharing insights on an interesting book I read by a blogger who has inspired my own fitness pursuits.

Having spent a great deal of time learning about and exploring many different kinds of diets, I’ve come across a lot of overly complicated explanations of how to eat healthy. Everyone seems to think their way is best, but I’ve found that the basic principles of diets that actually work are always the same: eat meals balanced in proteins, carbohydrates, and fats, made from fresh, high quality ingredients. Avoid too much sugar, and enjoy your food, eating when you’re hungry until you’re full. Whether it’s Paleo, Primal, Zone, Locavore, Vegtarian, Vegan, or Traditional, these principles always seem to hold. Of course, exponents of each diet focus on what makes them different, and this just leads to confusion. Vegans will tell you that eating meat leads to bodily decay, while the Paleo crowd will tell you that not eating meat leads to decrepitude.

item.title: Don't Just Face Your Fears, Learn to Love Them
item.description:
[caption id="attachment_1203" align="alignright" width="300" caption="epSos.de on Flickr"][/caption]

I must not fear. Fear is the mind-killer. Fear is the little-death that brings total obliteration. I will face my fear. I will permit it to pass over me and through me. And when it has gone past I will turn the inner eye to see its path. Where the fear has gone there will be nothing. Only I will remain. -Bene Gesserit Litany Against Fear, Frank Herbert's Dune

I would say the thing that most scares us is the unfamiliar. We seem naturally wary of things that we don't know very well, even parts of ourselves that we haven't dealt with in a very long time. We also shy away from things we have simply never experienced before. Unfortunately, this includes many of the things we'd like to live up to and achieve. So we have a problem; anyone who wants to grow and develop as a human being, to achieve their true potential (aka, their Warrior Spirit), must go from what they know, through what they don't know, and therefore, must face their fears.

item.title: Happiness is a Choice
item.description:
[caption id="attachment_1199" align="alignright" width="300" caption="Jayel Aheram"][/caption]

Most People are about as happy as they make up their minds to be - Abraham Lincoln

While reading The 80/20 Principle, I was struck by how many useful strategies are presented for increasing one's happiness. Having spent most of my young adult life pursuing happiness and learning what behaviors and life situations lead to happiness, I was not struck so much by the idea that you can cultivate happiness as by the new approaches to the old problem. I had always taken it for granted that I could be more or less happy, and that was in my control. So it came as a bit of a shock for me when the author spent the larger portion of the section on happiness trying to convince his readers that they happiness was something they could actually control. He cited all sorts of studies and authors showing that people have a say in their happiness level, that we are not simply at the mercy of circumstances.

item.title: Book Review: The 80/20 Principle
item.description:
[caption id="attachment_1194" align="alignright" width="104" caption="By Richard Koch"][/caption]

Here's an amazing, and disturbing, truth: 80% of anything that gets accomplished in your life comes from only 20% of your effort or time. 80% of your grades come from 20% of your studying. 80% of your productivity at work (and therefore the value of your income) comes from only 20% of actual time spent working. 80% of my quality writing is done in only 20% of the time I spend trying to write.

This idea - that most of what gets done is due to a minority of the causes - is the basis behind the 80/20 principle. The book, by Richard Koch, explains this concept and then illustrates what the 80/20 principle means for your real, everyday life. The subtitle, "the secret of success by achieving more with less," is a pretty enticing promise, and I believe that Koch delivers on this promise. This book will change the way you see the world, and should be read by anyone interested in achieving their potential.

item.title: The Importance of Serving Others in Personal Growth
item.description:
[caption id="attachment_1188" align="alignright" width="225" caption="Forest Runner on Flickr"][/caption]

“It is literally true that you can succeed best and quickest by helping others to succeed.” -Napoleon Hill

So much about the Warrior Spirit is centered around independence and self-sufficiency. I talk a lot about the need to stick to our own convictions and believe in our own dreams. There is a lot of standing up against the tide of mediocrity that tries to bring us back into the fold, a lot of fighting for our best lives and the life we want. So it may come as a bit of a shock when I say that a true Warrior is not complete if he only pursues his own goals.

In fact, the purpose of developing the self is so that you can serve others better.

item.title: Making Your Own Time
item.description:
[caption id="attachment_1183" align="alignright" width="300" caption="psyberartist on Flickr"][/caption]

“Our body is a well-set clock, which keeps good time, but if it be too much or indiscreetly tampered with, the alarm runs out before the hour” -Joseph Hall

I left my gym. Cross Country season is over. I have absolutely no set, recurring commitments at the moment. I haven't had this much freedom to pick my own activities since...before preschool. The scary part is that I'm not completely at a loss of what to do. Without any boundaries on how I use my time, I would have expected myself to go completely crazy and panic at the prospect of no external structure. Instead, I see before myself a blank canvas, and I've got a lot more colors to paint with than I ever have before. My day is mine to use as I see fit.

item.title: Why I Left My Job: To Start Again
item.description:
[caption id="attachment_1177" align="alignright" width="300" caption="Stevie Rocco on Flickr"][/caption]

“To learn something new, take the path that you took yesterday.” - John Burroughs

Today was my last day at the CrossFit gym where I had worked for the past year as a coach and personal trainer. I decided several weeks ago to leave the gym and pursue other opportunities on my own, and I finally took the step of leaving. It was a difficult decision, not so much because of financial reasons, but more because I loved working with the amazing athletes and dedicated individuals who came to train with us. Nevertheless, I am excited to be moving forward with my plans, even though there is a great degree of apprehension regarding my financial security. I feel that sometimes we have to pull apart everything we've built for ourselves to build something new, or backtrack the path we've already been down to look for new turn-offs with a better idea of where we want to go this time.

item.title: My Story
item.description:
“Today you are You, that is truer than true. There is no one alive who is Youer than You.” - Dr. Seuss

Based on the responses I got from all of you on that survey I sent out, most of the interest in what I write comes from knowing me. So I thought I'd write out my story, so those of you who didn't know me before the blog can understand where I'm coming from, where I get my stories and interpretations, and why I care so much about standing up to mediocrity and forging my own destiny.

item.title: Life Lessons from Philosophy: Socrates
item.description:
I am the wisest man in Athens, for I know one thing, and that is that I know nothing. -Socrates

This is a guest post from my friend David, an avid philosophizer and community development manager at the Family Refuge Center. He's the guy in the front of the canoe.

One’s first philosophy class is, almost certainly, like a glass of Champaign: 80% froth, 20% golden delight.  Indeed, class discussion was probably a maddening waste of time, and the lecturer was forever pandering to the behests of the idiots; but there were kernels of wisdom to be digested, if you knew where to look.  The first item you read was, undoubtedly, Plato’s account of the Trial of Socrates.  Within this dialogue, you could not have possibly ignored that the wisest man- in the wisest city- claimed to know nothing at all.  This kernal personifies the phrase: "hiding in plain sight" for as it is echoed innumerably, for most, it is passed over like a thrift store gem in a heap of dusty trifles.

item.title: Book Review: Strengths Finder 2.0
item.description:
[caption id="attachment_1048" align="alignright" width="116" caption="Clicking this image will take you to Amazon.com"][/caption]

Hide not your talents. They for use were made. What is a sundial in the shade?" - Benjamin Franklin

Do you really know what you are good at? Or are you, like most people, more aware of your failings than your strengths? And how much of your time is spent doing things you are really good at?

The truth is, most people (70% according to the Gallup organization) do not get to work at something they are good at. Most of their time is spent doing a job or duty which they find frustrating, difficult, or unintuitive. This costs them their sense of self-esteem, job satisfaction, and productivity, making them resent their work and perform poorly.

According to Tom Rath, author of StrengthsFinder 2.0
, this is a situation that can be remedied to the benefit of organization and individuals.

item.title: If You Want to Be Liked, Don't Try
item.description:
[caption id="attachment_1043" align="alignright" width="300" caption="moose.boy on Flickr"][/caption]

You follow what you feel inside
It's intuitive, you don't have to try
It comes naturally, mmmm it comes naturally

And it takes my breath away
What you do, so naturally

You are the thunder and I am the lightening
And I love the way you know who you are
And to me it's exciting

- Selena Gomez, "Naturally"

A friend of mine in the services industry is finding the customer relation aspect to be somewhat taxing. No matter how hard she works, there always seems to be some customer who decides to complain anyway. Even when she is doing everything right, someone finds something to criticize. As a very driven individual who always expects the best from herself, she has been trying very hard to rise to the challenges posed and improve her performance, but this doesn't seem to be helping. Customers still sometimes complain or whine or antagonize her.

item.title: Branding Our Lives
item.description:
[caption id="attachment_1039" align="alignright" width="194" caption="Call to Adventure on Flickr"][/caption]

"It’s time to stop this madness. The corporation is a hungry beast, and we keep feeding it. Let’s walk away, and let it die from hunger. Let’s free ourselves, and create a world where living things are more important than profits." -Leo Babauta, Mnmlist

Make all your own food. Buy all your manufactured goods from individual craftsmen. Learn how to sew and knit. Do your own repairs. Build your own furniture or buy it from a local carpenter. Don't buy the latest fashion trends. Exercise on your own, at home, with no or very little equipment. Entertain yourself instead of watching TV and movies.

Most Americans find these suggestions inconvenient, if not downright unpatriotic. We are conditioned to rely on corporations for our stuff and livelihoods.

item.title: Learning the Limits of My Experience
item.description:
[caption id="attachment_1035" align="alignright" width="300" caption="Johan J.Ingles-Le Nobel on Flickr"][/caption]

“As I have said, the first thing is to be honest with yourself. You can never have an impact on society if you have not changed yourself... Great peacemakers are all people of integrity, of honesty, but humility.” -Nelson Mandela

I went for a 5k run today, the first I've undertaken in over a year. Despite all the intense anaerobic exercise I do at CrossFit, the fact that I can run a 5:05 mile, and my powerful legs, I found it extremely difficult. So difficult, in fact, that I walked near the end and got a time that was worse than my best high school time. My ankles are sore and I feel more beat up than usual. But really, I'm not that surprised I didn't do as well as I thought I could. After all, I may be a very well-rounded athlete, but I know that distance running has become a definite area of neglect in my training.

item.title: Link Love: Annamal House
item.description:
I don’t know what I want to be when I grow up, but I hope I become something good. - Anna

Eating differently is hard. It's like being a Yankee fan in Boston, except suddenly everywhere is Boston. There is no real reason why everyone else decides you're messed up and not worth talking to. They do it simply on principle. So when someone decides to eat differently, they are signing up for being the perpetual oddball, the person you'd think twice about inviting to a party just because feeding them will be so annoyingly complicated.

Except Anna is definitely not the kind of person you'd think twice about inviting to a party. Anna is the kind of person you'd build the invite list around. And Anna is a vegan, the most extreme and obnoxiously complicated type of person to feed (I know because my sister was one).

item.title: If Failure is Not An Option, You Won't Fail
item.description:
[caption id="attachment_1030" align="alignright" width="300" caption="wolfsavard on Flickr"][/caption]

"Do or do not. There is no try." - Yoda, Return of the Jedi

I have recently learned a back handspring, and a front flip, among some other more complex gymnastics moves. Every time I want to try one without my coach to spot me, he considers whether I'm ready, nods and says, "Alright, give it a shot. The chance of seriously injuring yourself is probably less than 60/40." He is joking, sort of, but it is true that many of the stunts I attempt are actually quite dangerous. And that is why I don't mess up. Without safety nets, I can't afford to fail.

item.title: Choose Your Words Carefully
item.description:
[caption id="attachment_1023" align="alignright" width="300" caption="Horia Varlan on Flickr"][/caption]

"We cannot always control our thoughts, but we can control our words, and repetition impresses the subconscious, and we are then master of the situation." - Florence Scovel Shinn Artist, Teacher and Author

The words we use to convey our thoughts and describe our lives influence the way we see the world to a greater extent than most of us realize. It may not seem like a big difference, but choosing to use one word or descriptor over another can help you overcome negative or constraining worldviews. Think about how you talk about your goals. Do you refer to them as dreams or as concrete objectives? Do you talk to yourself in the first or second person? Do you refer to other people using condescending terms ('girls' for all women)? Such subtle changes in the language you use will, over time, change the way you think about people and how others deal with you.

item.title: Thinking Outside the Box You Built Yourself
item.description:
[caption id="attachment_1016" align="alignright" width="262" caption="Steve Keys on Flickr"][/caption]

“There are people who put their dreams in a little box and say, "Yes, I've got dreams, of course I've got dreams." Then they put the box away and bring it out once in awhile to look in it, and yep, they're still there.” -Emma Bombeck

Since I was a little kid, I was taught that I could not support myself doing something fun that I loved. I would have to find a job that tediously 'contributed' to society in order to make enough money so I'd have the resources to spend my free time engaged in enjoyable 'hobbies'. Life would always be a trade off between doing what you had to, based on what someone else deemed was a valuable use of your time, and doing what you wanted.

Recently, I've begun to question the assumption that doing something you enjoy is a poor way to make money. Of course, if you're really lucky, you'll end up in a job you love, so money-making will be bearable, but the emphasis was on fitting yourself into a job, rather than the other way around.

item.title: Responsibilities to Animals
item.description:
[caption id="attachment_1007" align="alignright" width="266" caption="GDS Infographics on Flickr"][/caption]

“I like pigs. Dogs look up to us. Cats look down on us. Pigs treat us as equals.” -Winston Churchill

I have recently been volunteering as a cat cuddler (yes that is as awesome as it sounds) and a dog walker at the local humane society. My responsibilities involve socializing the abandoned animals. Many people don't realize how hard it is for a dog or cat to be left behind or given away. The animal feels betrayed and can respond by becoming aggressive or exceedingly timid. It is so sad to see little puppies and kittens hiding scared, though they tend to rebound quickly and make new friends. The hardest thing is seeing an older animal too timid to come out of its cage.

item.title: Why I Love Working with Kids
item.description:
[caption id="attachment_1001" align="alignright" width="300" caption="are you my rik? on Flickr"][/caption]

All I really need to know about how to live and what to do and how to be I learned in kindergarten. Wisdom was not at the top of the graduate school mountain, but there in the sand pile at school. - Robert Fulghum

Children give you a lot of perspective on life. They are impossible to keep in order, except when you do seemingly trivial and silly things. They seem very rude and uncouth most of the time, but the best way to get them to do what you want is simply to ask nicely. They remind you what's important in life, and the importance of friends, food, and enough rest. They also teach you how to appreciate the little things in life, like the wonder of floating on a surfboard in the sun (something I find endlessly tedious) and how stupid things can be really, legitimately funny.

item.title: Learn to Stand Alone
item.description:
[caption id="attachment_998" align="alignright" width="300" caption="faungg on Flickr"][/caption]

"Never tell your problems to anyone...20% don't care and the other 80% are glad you have them.." - Lou Holtz

One of the most frustrating aspects of life is that whenever you become passionate about pursuing some extraordinary goal or lifestyle, people waste no time in trying to hold you back. I find it odd that people rarely go out of their way to encourage your ambitions, but they will eagerly jump into a conversation to provide reasons you are wrong, might fail, or wasting your time. Especially if they have to change some aspect of their lives to accommodate you, they will do their utmost to convince you that your desire to run off and contribute to world peace will absolutely end their livliehoods.

item.title: Healthy Ice Cream Alternatives
item.description:
[caption id="attachment_988" align="alignright" width="300" caption="jessicafm on Flickr"][/caption]

"You scream, I scream, we all scream for ice cream!" - American Proverb

Ice cream is probably the greatest food ever invented by humankind. But it is also probably one of the least healthy. It is basically milk and sugar, plus any flavorings and toppings. Of course, ice cream isn't meant to be healthy, so it should be an occasional treat, but sometimes you just have a craving for it when you know you can't or shouldn't break out the scoop and fudge sauce.

item.title: Freedom-Promoting Jobs
item.description:
[caption id="" align="alignright" width="400" caption="Candlemaker on Flickr"][/caption]

This is a repost of an article I wrote for another blog on career advice for young people.

“You just have to do your own thing, no matter what anyone says. It's your life.” - Ethan Embry

There are plenty of reasons out there why you would want to avoid a job like the plague. After all, there is a reason Robert Kiyosaki, author of Rich Dad, Poor Dad, refers to the dreaded word as a mere acronym for Just Over Broke. Nevertheless, getting a job is the easiest way there is to make money, if not necessarily the most desirable, and as such is an invaluable method for providing the necessary foundation to jump off to freedom. Let’s be ridiculous and say we want a job with few hours, lots of freedom, and plenty of money. Where on earth do you find one like that? Before we go on, let me define what exactly I mean when I say Job.

item.title: The Process of Living
item.description:
[caption id="attachment_974" align="alignright" width="225" caption="Source: mdezemery on flickr"][/caption]

"The journey is what brings us happiness not the destination." -Dan Millman, The Peaceful Warrior

One of the overriding themes that I refer to a lot is the idea that many important endeavors are ongoing. There is no end goal in mind, and having an end goal can often derail our efforts to improve. Instead, simply going through your routine, growing slowly and naturally, will get you where you want to go with less frustration and less pain.

item.title: The End of Competition
item.description:
[caption id="attachment_967" align="alignright" width="300" caption="Source: thaiqn on Flickr"][/caption]

“It is the character of a brave and resolute man not to be ruffled by adversity and not to desert his post” - Marcus Tullius Cicero

My old school no longer plays dodgeball. It is against the rules. The children are urged to forget the game. In fact, we no longer play any games with a score, for fear of engendering competition. The fear is that kids will lord it over one another, put down the losers and gloat in their victory. They will brag and tease and ostracize their peers, or will feel hurt and put down. Some parents and administrators probably worry that kids who lose at dodgeball are more likely to do something violent to vent their frustration. I think this prevents kids from developing strong character.

item.title: You Are What Your Ancestors Ate
item.description:
[caption id="attachment_962" align="alignright" width="300" caption="Source: alexdecarvalho on Flickr"][/caption]

Meat and veggies, nuts and seeds, some fruit, little starch, and no sugar -The Paleo Diet in a nutshell

Many of my friends know I follow an approximately Paleo diet, and a lot of people argue with me as to why it is silly to eat like Paleolithic humans. I thought I would take the time to dispel some myths and misunderstandings about this 'diet', and hopefully win a few converts.

item.title: The Benefits of Time Spent Outdoors
item.description:
[caption id="attachment_954" align="alignright" width="222" caption="Source: ©Hεαṿεṉlÿ Phøτøģɾαρhÿ on Flickr"][/caption]

Man's heart away from nature becomes hard.  -Standing Bear

The natural world is all around us. Every city is merely an island of human habitation amidst a vast sea of countryside and forests. A mere hour outside of New York, one of the biggest metropolises in the world, one can find beautiful and surprisingly isolated parks and hiking trails. The hills around LA are still pretty wild (apparently coyotes are a major concern out there). Most cities have parks, little spaces where the city's fabric is cut out to reveal the nature underneath, just waiting to burst through into sunlight. These are places people can go to escape the hustle of the city for a while. There is something calming and serene about nature. I always feel complete and more balanced when surrounded by trees, and there is a lot to be said for seeking out a regular connection with the outdoors.

item.title: Guide to Warrior Spirit
item.description: You have probably noticed all the changes that have taken place recently around here. I just want to make sure everyone knows how things will be run from now on. The main changes have been the new subscription services and the posting schedule, as well as the focus of the posts. Here's a breakdown of what's new and what's to come.

item.title: Zen Habits Handbook for Life
item.description:
[caption id="attachment_950" align="alignright" width="300" caption="Source: kristofabrath on Flickr"][/caption]

Smile, breathe, and go slowly - Thich Nhat Hanh

Back when I was in college, drowning under the immense workload and the complexities of balancing my social life, personal life, and scholastic commitments, I stumbled upon a blog that saved my academic standing as well as my sanity. The blog is called Zen Habits, and it was a godsend.

item.title: Unconventional Fitness Truths
item.description:
[caption id="attachment_883" align="alignright" width="199" caption="Source: JcOlivera.com on Flickr"][/caption]

“A bear, however hard he tries, grows tubby without exercise.” -Winnie the Pooh

Since I began CrossFit two years ago, I've learned some things about fitness that seem very counterintuitive. When I started training other people, one of my biggest challenges had been convincing people that what they've always thought about fitness is wrong. Here are some common misconceptions that I've discovered to be false, along with some strange truths that you wouldn't suspect.

item.title: How to Beat Procrastination
item.description:
[caption id="attachment_789" align="alignright" width="199" caption="Source: CraigGrocott on Flickr"][/caption]

“Do it now! can affect every phase of your life. It can help you do the things you should do but don't feel like doing. It can keep you from procrastinating when an unpleasant duty faces you. But it can also help you do those things that you want to do. It helps you seize those precious moments that, if lost, may never be retrieved.” - Napoleon Hill

Thank you for reading my blog today, but I have to ask, is there something more important you have to do that you are putting off by checking in? (Or perhaps reading my blog is the most important thing you have to do today, in which case I'm flattered :)). Procrastination, the sacred art of putting things off to the last minute, is one of the biggest productivity killers in our lives, and also one of the biggest sources of stress and anxiety. It is a learned habit, one that can really mess with your sense of well-being and mental health. It cuts into all aspects of our lives, from reading, to shopping, to paying bills, to exercising. So why do we procrastinate, and how can we eliminate this habit?

item.title: What Do You Call Yourself?
item.description:
[caption id="attachment_772" align="alignright" width="300" caption="Source: pinprick on Flickr"][/caption]

“They stick you with those names, those labels -- ‘rebel’ or whatever; whatever they like to use. Because they need a label; they need a name. They need something to put the price tag on the back of.” - Johnny Depp

When people ask you what you do, what do you say? What would you like to say? Most people answer with their current job: "I am a personal trainer," or "I sell commodities," or "I'm a homemaker." These sorts of answers are sufficient to move the conversation along, but most people 'do' so much more than their job. Perhaps the question is actually a poorly worded version of, "What is your job?" I think that is only because of habit. I don't think most people care if you answer with your job or some other activity that occupies your time. So why not give an answer that really describes what it is you do?

item.title: The Meaning of Integrity: The Complete Human
item.description:
[caption id="attachment_767" align="alignright" width="225" caption="Source: poeticaldistractions on Flickr"][/caption]

“The truth of the matter is that you always know the right thing to do. The hard part is doing it.” - General Norman Schwarzkopf

This blog is largely about the development of character. The most important quality of character is integrity, because without it, character has no meaning. So what is integrity, anyway? The word is vaguely defined in most discussions, and looking back over my posts, I realize I have never actually clarified what it is I am talking about.

item.title: Don't Be Afraid to Reach for Your Goals
item.description:
[caption id="attachment_746" align="alignright" width="300" caption="Source: ~dip on Flickr"][/caption]

People have a lot of preconceived notions about what they deserve: what they deserve to be called, what they deserve to have, what they deserve to be paid, who they deserve to love and be loved by. We set limits on our own potential, not because we want to hold ourselves back, but rather because we think it is the just way. The thought pattern might go like this: "I've only been writing regularly for a few weeks, so I don't deserve a published novel." Ironically, people often are afraid to reach for their goals, because they don't think they are worthy of them.

item.title: Why You Should Blow it All to Travel
item.description:
[caption id="attachment_743" align="alignright" width="300" caption="Source: DragonWoman on Flickr"][/caption]

We know that travel is essential to a complete education. Traveling abroad teaches understanding of other people, cultures and communities, and these types of experiences offer young people a greater ability to be successful in today's global society. - Michael Palmer

An old friend from my days interning at Forbes gave me some interesting advice today. As a well-established manager, she would have been able to make a very good argument for starting to seriously look at a career, putting down professional roots, building up my financial profile and really setting myself up for the long, steady path to independence and security. Instead, she pretty much recommended I risk it all and travel, try to work in some other countries, because, after all at my age and in this economic climate, there isn't much to lose. Take the big risks while you're young.

item.title: 5 Simple Ways to Be Healthier
item.description:
[caption id="attachment_737" align="alignright" width="300" caption="Source: KOREA.NET on flickr"][/caption]

Tea is drunk to forget the din of the world. -T’ien Yiheng

In the last few years, I've spent a lot of time finding ways to be healthier without dedicating huge chunks of time or money that I don't have. While a lot of the success I've come across has been the result of some pretty big changes, I have found that the most basic and important things come from small changes. Increased energy levels, better sleep, better digestion, feeling calmer and more relaxed, less pain, and better relationships have all been the result of the smaller, cheaper alternations I've made to my life. When these things fall off, problems occur. Here are some really small changes you can make to improve your life in noticeable ways.

item.title: Why We Love the Status Quo
item.description:
[caption id="attachment_733" align="alignright" width="296" caption="Source: pobrecito33 on Flickr"][/caption]

Losses loom larger than corresponding gains

Would you rather make $100 with a small possibility of losing $75 instead, or would you rather make $25 with no potential to lose anything? If you are like most people, you would select the second option. This despite the fact that there is potentially greater benefit to the first option. This is because people will rather hold on to what they have now than risk losing it for something better. We worry that we'll never get back to what we had. This phenomenon is called Loss Aversion in the fields of decision-making and economics.

item.title: The Importance of Listening
item.description:
[caption id="attachment_729" align="alignright" width="300" caption="Source: Ro/wererabbit on Flickr"][/caption]

When we talk about something, we just talk about something, just the positive or the negative side, without trying to express some intellectual, one-sided idea. And we listen without trying to figure out some intellectual understanding, without trying ot understand from just a one-sided view. - Shunryu Suzuki

A friend of mine recently wrote a Facebook note in which he mentioned some thoughts on conversations. Specifically, he maintained that it was better to have few conversations, because most people aren't very good at having conversations. Most people, states my friend, will be quick to follow random tangents in any discussion, never really making any headway on the issue you'd like to discuss. In the end, they are more concerned with their own agenda than participating in the conversation at hand.

item.title: Lessons on Friendship from Camp
item.description:
[caption id="attachment_721" align="alignright" width="300" caption="Source: sausyn on Flickr"][/caption]

We could learn a lot from crayons; some are sharp, some are pretty, some are dull, while others bright, some have weird names, but they all have to share the same box -Anon

I spent a great deal of my childhood at a wonderful summer camp in Northern Minnesota, where it seemed like everyone was a potential friend and all the friends you made were true friends. How great would that be in real life? So often the friends we make have agendas, or only hang around us at certain times and with certain people. There is often a sense of insincerity, or somewhat impure friendship. But at Summer Camp, the friends you made at horseback riding were just as good for sailing (assuming they could sail), and you could eat with them, camp with them, play games with them, or just sit and watch the lake together. There is a strange and wondrous ease about camp friends that is so rare and hard to find elsewhere.

item.title: Returning to the Dojo: The Importance of Martial Arts
item.description:
[caption id="attachment_713" align="alignright" width="201" caption="Source: Pieter Baert on Flickr"][/caption]

Ever since I was a child I have had this instinctive urge for expansion and growth. To me, the function and duty of a quality human being is the sincere and honest development of one's potential. - Bruce Lee

Yesterday, I attended my first class of American Kenpo Karate in over five years. My old teacher told me in an e-mail to bring my old Gi, which I had kept, anticipating an eventual return to the art. When I went to dig it out from a trunk under my bed, I found my old belts, one soft, well-worn, and white, and the other stiff and bright, un-faded yellow. I grabbed the white belt and headed to class.

When I stepped into the dance studio where the class was being held, my old instructor, taller and leaner than I remembered, looked at me without recognition. It had been a long time. He was shocked at the growth he saw in me and had trouble connecting the old Khaled with the one who stood before him. And then he looked down and saw I was wearing my old white belt and asked, "Where's your belt?"

item.title: Eliminating Distractions
item.description:
[caption id="attachment_702" align="alignright" width="300" caption="Source: tychay on Flickr"][/caption]

If while washing dishes, we think only of the cup of tea that awaits us, thus hurrying to get the dishes out of the way as if they were a nuisance, then we are not "washing the dishes to wash the dishes." What's more, we are not alive during the time we are washing the dishes.... While drinking the cup of tea, we will only be thinking of other things, barely aware of the cup in our hands. Thus we are sucked away into the future -and we are incapable of actually living one minute of life. - Naht Hahn, Miracle of Mindfulness

Modern technology is a wonderful thing. It gives us access to more information than we could possibly ever hope to read and understand. It connects us to people all over the world and lets us share ideas and conversations with them on a whim. It puts the entirety of human knowledge at our fingertips. As a college student, I was infinitely grateful for the fact that I could do almost all my research and class readings online without having to spend hours in the bookstacks looking for texts. At the click of a button, I could bring to my attention the latest psychological research and in the same breath skim an article on current events.

item.title: Freedom Through Discipline
item.description:
[caption id="attachment_695" align="alignright" width="225" caption="Source: Laniee75 on Flickr"][/caption]

“Seek freedom and become captive of your desires. Seek discipline and find your liberty.” - Frank Herbert

I used to follow a very strict diet, and was religious about exercising. Rain or shine, groggy or energetic, sugar cravings or not, I followed my program. Ultimately, it turned out my particular program was a little intense and led to some problems, and so I have lately abandoned it for a more intuitive approach, meaning I do things when I feel like it, meaning I often don't do what I'm supposed to do. At first, this felt liberating, but I've begun to realize that I have given up something very important by letting go of my confining routines: my freedom.

item.title: Do-It-Yourself Living
item.description:
[caption id="attachment_687" align="alignright" width="199" caption="Source: Rob Joyce & Alex on Flickr"][/caption]

“The only Zen you find on tops of mountains is the Zen you bring there” - Robert M. Pirsig
I have lately started reading the very inspirational Zen Mind, Beginner's Mind, by Shunryu Suzuki. This book is a collection of essays on Zen and it is both calming and enlightening to read. One of the overriding themes is the fact that Zen is not something external or alien to us. It already exists within us, in the nature of our minds, bodies, and spirits. Enlightenment is not found in some faraway spiritual realm, or even down the road. Rather, it is right there in your grasp. It is your grasp.

item.title: Life on a Whim
item.description:
[caption id="" align="alignleft" width="500" caption="Source: sea turtle on Flickr"][/caption]

I've noticed that some of my best decisions are made on a whim. That is, the less I consider a decision, the better it turns out. My worst decisions are made with a minimum of consideration, and I made decent choices after careful thought. But the things that make me happiest tend to be done with zero forethought.

item.title: Time Magazine Explodes the Organic Myth, Kind Of
item.description:
[caption id="attachment_670" align="alignright" width="300" caption="Source: Digital Wallpapers on Flickr"][/caption]

Yesterday, the latest issue of Time Magazine arrived in the mail. And right on the cover was a blurb about an article on "The Organic Food Debate." I have some familiarity with the so called 'debate.' It basically boils down to this: organic/clean/sustainable/local food is great in theory, but it is too expensive/elitist/not scalable. I have seen this sort of article several times, so I had a pretty good idea of the arguments to come, but I credit Time with a willingness to tackle tough issues and the integrity to present ambivalent conclusions. So I turned to the page and started reading.

item.title: Is Athleticism Good for Your Health?
item.description:
[caption id="" align="alignright" width="333" caption="Source: RobW_ on Flickr"][/caption]

A recent visit to my sports doctor, brought on by yet another overuse injury, prompted me to wonder if being an athlete is actually good for one's health and fitness. After all, the only reason I was at the doctor was because I am an athlete. I had injured my shoulder on a leisurely kayak tour of a small Connecticut lake. The shoulder was prone to such a pansy injury because I regularly engage in extreme fitness, aka, CrossFit.

Now, you are probably wondering, as was I, how can an athlete with shoulders capable of doing multiple strict muscle-ups be completely incapacitated by something as tame as kayaking? I honestly don't have an answer. But the experience got me to wondering about the distinctions between fitness, health, and athleticism.

item.title: Abundance and Scarcity Thinking
item.description:
[caption id="" align="aligncenter" width="500" caption="Source: incurable_hippie on Flickr"][/caption]

I tend to get really sleepy around 9pm. This drives my friends crazy, since that is when they normally hang out, and it is about when I start thinking about turning in. They wonder why I'm so energetically spent all the time, and my answer, ironically, is that it's because I exercise a lot. Besides that, I would explain that I have to get up at 5am a couple times a week, or 6:30 at the latest. This was an excuse I'd use for myself as well, to justify my general desire to do less and sleep more. I just didn't have the energy to spare.

Last week, I learned a lesson from a good friend, who actually recently joined my gym. He shows up to all my morning classes, and all the other morning classes, and he is the one who is always trying to keep me up past 9pm. We were hanging out, late by my standards, and I was acting tired. When someone commented on it, I slipped into my usual explanation and my friend immediately jumped in to say that he got up at the same time every day. That shut me up pretty quick.

item.title: A New Way to Run
item.description:
[caption id="" align="alignright" width="350" caption="Source: José Goulão on Flickr"][/caption]

Running is probably the most basic of human movements, besides walking. As an exercise, its benefits and usefulness are unparalleled. If I had to give up all but one mode of exercise, the one I'd keep would be running in all its glorious manifestations: contemplative jogs, serene trail runs, tense hustles, heart-about-to-explode sprints. It is my favorite physical activity involving clothes (most of the time). Because it is so closely related to walking, we take to it pretty naturally. Nobody has to learn how to run in the way we learn how to swim or bike. You simply put one foot in front of the other, faster and faster and faster.

item.title: Conscious Living for Young People
item.description:
Our children don't inherit the Earth from us. We are borrowing it from them.

- Unknown

Idealism can be a frustrating trait to have. You have such dreams and aspirations, most of which are far beyond your current capabilities. Once your acquire the means to realize your ambitions, you have become so reliant on the system you wanted to change that your idealism has faded to 'mature pragmatism.' It is us young people that have so many concerns about living healthy, respecting and protecting the environment, giving our time to help our communities. But it is not until we are older that we have the resources to do that. Oftentimes, acquiring those resources, and the stability and time needed to dedicate those resources, comes at the cost of our activist-souls. As Rich Dad, Poor Dad illustrates, we find ourselves shackled by a mortgage, a 'safe, secure job', and debt. Thoughts of changing the world are set aside as we struggle to simply get by. Eco-consciousness becomes something we do at the grocery store by 'buying green', and community engagement comes in the form of sending a monthly check to the neighborhood association you never interact with. You know cars are bad, but you've got kids who need to get to soccer games, the grocery store is miles away, and the SUV is just so much more useful.

item.title: Lyrics for a Pirate Song I Wrote
item.description:
This song was inspired by a class on American globalization, which covered the development of the seaborne economy of the 1600s and 1700s, as well as the scallywags who fought for democracy and freedom on the high seas (that was the authors' interpretation of piracy: a means to escape the crushing yoke of 'ye olde man').

*To be sung in a heavy pirate accent*

Pirate Song Yarrrr
[CHORUS]
Yo ho, yo ho
Yo ho and a bottle of a rum!
Yo ho, yo ho,
A pirate's life for me!
They call me a pirate
Cause I sail seven seas
The royal navy’s after me
But I’ll always be free

item.title: Conserving Water, Water Everywhere
item.description:
I recently saw the new remake of Karate Kid, starring Jared Smith and Jackie Chan. Overall, it was a great movie, full of inspiring struggles to overcome adversity and useful advice about growing up and facing challenges. It also made an interesting comment on consumption patterns. And there were some awesome Kung Fu sequences.

As it turns out, in China, you must flip a switch to start preparing for a hot shower. The switch heats up the water, and when you're done taking your shower, you turn it off. It saves money and electricity, for obvious reasons. Jared's character doesn't understand this and asks, "Why not just keep it on?" Jackie Chan is surprised and appalled to discover that in America, we don't even have a switch. We just keep the hot water on all the time! He leaves Jared with this bit of advice: "Get switch. Save money. Save the planet."

item.title: Stop Struggling and Suddenly Everything Clicks
item.description: A strange thing happened recently. My life went from being hectic, disorganized, and frustrating to suddenly clear and productive. This happened without any warning, and without any real discernible change in my circumstances. In the same way that you feel a lot lighter and calmer when you realize you've been restricting your breathing and start taking deep breaths, something in my mindset that was cramped and tight simply relaxed. This has had a number of interesting effects:

item.title: Minimalism in Writing: Getting to the Point
item.description:
I love to write. People know this about me, and my parents have long encouraged the habit. As a result, I used to get a lot of writing-themed books as gifts. One particular type of book always made me feel inadequate as a writer: speciality dictionaries, full of strange and esoteric words (even more esoteric than 'esoteric') that a well-educated shaper of the English language ought to master and use in everyday speech. The problem was, I didn't really care to learn all these new words. So the books sat on my shelf, collecting dust, because I kept telling myself that, one day, I'd get around to memorizing all these new, important words and incorporating them into my writing.

I'm glad I never did.

item.title: Midwest Trip Wrap-Up
item.description:
[caption id="attachment_622" align="alignright" width="300" caption="Graffiti Graveyard, Duluth, MN"][/caption]

Apologies for the delay. Upon arriving home I discovered my home in the midst of packing to move and have thus been distracted.

Logistics from Hell

Upon leaving Wisconsin, I made my way, via bus, to the Twin Cities of Minneapolis-St. Paul. Even though I'm not from the state, whenever anyone refers to 'the cities' it is this metropolis I immediately think of, even when I'm elsewhere. The bus ride was uneventful, except for the fact that I missed my first bus and then had to negotiate my way on to the next bus out. 5-minutes of lateness cost me $80 in new bus far and a taxi ride.

More logistical problems at the MSP airport prevented me from renting a car from my originally planned company. I thought I'd be stuck completely but they recommended me to another company, which actually ended up costing me less. So it worked out in the end, I made it out of the cities and got on the long, beautiful, pine-wrapped highway of Minnesota, en route to the Northwoods and the lake country.

Lesson: This was exactly the fear that had kept me from travelling in the first place. I dealt with it and got to the places I wanted to go. So I learned that I am smart enough and resourceful enough to manage if things go astray. Still, the reliance on my own cash was a little unsettling. What if I ran out of money? I have long ago stopped carrying Daddy's Credit Card.

Memory Lane on I-35

The drive up to camp was relaxing. I'd been on the road all day anyway, but it was nice to drive my own (rented) car. I got up to camp around 11:30, feeling completely at home like always. I managed to find some people who knew me sharing a fire in the sailing house and sat with them for an hour, hanging out like we'd been seeing each other all year. There was very little catch up talk and a lot of comfortable silence and random tangents. I slept in a cabin, all alone, which I should know by now is a bad idea. No matter how old I get, the intermediate cabins freak me out with all the windows open and their big, empty wooden rooms. I spent many a summer night as a kid bawling my eyes out in terror in those cabins, and old memories like that never really fade completely. While not afraid per se, I was unconsciously tense all night and didn't actually manage to fall asleep until the sun came up, lulled by the haunting call of the loon and the wind in the pines.

item.title: Connecting the Dots: Midwest Trip Update
item.description:
[caption id="attachment_616" align="alignright" width="300" caption="Annie Mole on Flickr"][/caption]

So, for those of you who don't know, I've been out travelling since Monday, reconnecting with all the places and as many people as I can that had an impact on me in the past year. I don't know why it was last year that made the difference, but I felt very much like there was a lot of loose ends to tie up. I'm not at all sure what specifically those loose ends were, but they were there. So I finally just bought a ticket to Chicago and started my trip. Loose ends revealed themselves, and more importantly, methods for tying (or rather, connecting them to other, more integral threads) were slowly uncovered.

item.title: Your Brain is Making You Weak
item.description:
There's a lot in the fitness community on how diet and exercise impact fitness and strength, and even a fair amount on sleep. Less discussed is the impact of mental state and the way the nervous system can interact with muscles to have a huge impact on athletic performance and strength. Since I've been reading some alternative theories lately, I thought I'd share some things.

Nervous Inhibition

Here's an interesting fact: by default, the nervous system limits muscle tension to 30% of what the associated tendons can bear. So if you can only lift 100lbs, it's not because your muscles are weak, it's because your brain is holding you back to protect the tendons. Probably the biggest factor limiting how strong we are is our own nervous system keeping our muscles down to protect us. Another related phenomenon is that the brain will inhibit agonist (primary mover) muscles if it perceives the antagonist is weak, in order to protect the joint. For example, your bicep will be inhibited if your triceps is weak because the brain will worry that, should things get out of hand, the triceps won't be able to counteract the bicep force.

item.title: A Radical Idea
item.description: I have decided I do not want to work a real job for the rest of my life. Instead, I would like to do whatever I want, travelling, learning new skills, and pursuing my perfect day. I don't want to rely on a job where I have to show up to be paid as my main source of income. I would like to be paid to exist. Or, more accurately, I would like to be paid as the result of some service that I provide without actually needing to be present so I can do whatever I want instead, owning a business or investments being the main vehicle for this sort of thing. Writing a book being another. We shall see. Read on to see my plan for accomplishing this.

item.title: Why You Really Need to Clean Your Room
item.description: What is more characteristic of college and graduate aged people than a messy bedroom? Something about our natures necessitates living in filth and squalor, much to the chagrin of our parents, forced to visit and stay on our couch (unless they can afford a motel) or play host yet again as we struggle to find a job. The weird thing is, for a lot of us, we were actually pretty tidy back in the day. But now that we have our own place, why bother cleaning up? After all, I know exactly where my nice shirt is, even if that changes from day to day. It's not like our messy living spaces are unhygienic. A little inconvenient maybe, but it takes just as much time to clean and tidy as it does to search out our favorite pair of jeans.

item.title: My Engine is Bigger than Yours: Efficiency vs. Effectiveness in CrossFit
item.description: Generally, when presented with any given task, we seek out the most efficient way to complete that task. The less time it takes, the less effort involved, the better. Not so often do we ask ourselves whether we're doing the right task or not. Is what we are doing actually the most effective way to reach our goals, or is it just busy-work? A Honda is more efficient than a Ferrari, but a Ferrari will get your where you're going much, much faster, making it more effective if your goal is saving time in transit.

item.title: Up in the Air
item.description: I just finished watching the movie, Up in the Air. The main character Ryan Bingham, played by the masterful (and distressingly handsome) George Clooney, is in love with his unattached life. Unburdened by attachments to people, place, or things, he revels in travel and the complete freedom he has. During the movie, he begins to question his life, however, and contemplates something like a commitment to another person. Turns out that he can't really be a part of another person's 'real life,' and we are left wondering if his entire existence is composed of 'in betweens,' or at least whether or not he is capable of functioning except when he is up in the air.

item.title: Things I've Learned, This Year
item.description: Here are some random things I'm learning about/working through currently. Some of them are lessons and some are 'huh' moments. Mainly I've just wanted to get something up since I haven't updated in a bit, so this is what's going on in my life. Exciting I know...

item.title: Is Facebook controlling who your friends are?
item.description: Something I've noticed happened with Facebook and other social networks is that many of the friends I interact with online are not the same ones I'd normally interact with in person. In some cases, they are people I don't even enjoy being around in person, but are nevertheless fun and interesting to talk to in the sterile little chat box. This got me to thinking about how the mediums we use for social interaction affect that interaction. I'm certainly more flirtatious online than in person, but what if the effects go deeper than tone?

item.title: You'll Never Be Good Enough...Until You Are
item.description:
As an athlete, one of the most common de-motivators I deal with is the assertion, made either by myself or well-meaning friends trying to help me deal with frustration at limited progress, that professional and Olympic athletes (those I aspire to be like) are genetic abnormalities. Thus, I should not expect myself to perform at their level, and should not hold myself to similar expectations of progress.

Generally, I have agreed with this statement. After all, I'm just a genetically average human, right? Even with all the determination in the world (and I have plenty of that) I just don't have the right bone length, muscle fiber ratios, metabolic eccentricities, to make it to the big leagues. So I shouldn't even try, and certainly not become frustrated.

Then I realized I have no idea what my genetic make-up is. For all I know, I am an Olympic sprinter who just needs the right training to unleash his genetic potential. People tell me I'm too tall to be a gymnast, too lanky to be a good lifter, but there have been unlikely champions in every sport imaginable.

item.title: Self-Inflicted Wounds: The Gulf of Mexico Oil Spill
item.description:
I generally don't follow current events in much detail and prefer to stay uninvolved in politics. If I had my way, I'd require all children to be educated on the importance of the natural world, at the expense of more 'practical' subjects, but I tend to maintain some distance from most environmental issues, simply because they tend to be so heartbreaking, with so many angry people on both sides. To get emotionally involved would be like asking for a stress-induced heart attack.

Today, I read an article in Time about the Deep Horizon disaster. I had known what was going on, but was not aware of the extent of the damage. Reading it was like watching a horror movie; it was so horrific I wanted to cover my eyes, but something compelled me to keep reading, to subject myself to the terrible scenes and let the images of the ecological disaster crowd my mind. I felt my heart grow cold with fear for all the environmental damage that would and has occurred, all the diversity that would be lost and perhaps never recovered. I felt anger at the people who had allowed this to happen: the oil companies and our government. But most of all, I felt a deep sadness. How terrible that our civilization has come to this habit of destroying its most beautiful environments and coastlines for the sake of a few more years of dirty, smoggy convenience.

item.title: How to Give Direction to Your Life
item.description: When we enter college, we have no idea what we want to do with our lives. We get to spend the next four years discovering our interests academically, finding our social niche, and figuring out our professional futures so that when we graduate...we still have no idea what we want to do with our lives. The problem is multi-faceted, but hinges on the fact that college is not a reflection of the real world. The subjects are not applied as they would be, the social life is completely unique, and the reward system does not reflect how people find fulfillment outside of college. Furthermore, there is a lot of pressure in college to do what is best for our academic or professional future, and too often the focus is on short term requirements to meet various grant or internship criteria, not personal happiness.

item.title: Dealing with Injury
item.description:
[caption id="attachment_557" align="alignright" width="300" caption="It would be easier if they could put a cone on me to keep me from exercising when I'm injured"][/caption]

We all have times in our lives when we find ourselves unable to do the things we love, often because we did too much of the things we love. Whether it's cutting back on delicious pies because we had too many in one sitting last winter or cutting back our training load because we hurt ourselves, we get ourselves into situations that we regret, doing something we knew we shouldn't have done at the time, but did anyway.

item.title: Best Friends (for Life)
item.description: Some of you have asked who the people in the canoe on the top banner are. It's no surprise that one of them is me. The other person is a guy who has been like a brother to me since fifth grade, when I stumbled awkwardly on to the shores of this country, a naive Arab with no clue how to handle this overwhelming America, as it were. He took me under his wing, and attempted (in vain) to teach me the ways of the American schoolboy. Since then, we've been through almost everything together: we've gotten to the point of mutual hatred, we've come to appreciate the man-hug, we got our Eagle Scout badges at the same time and held a joint ceremony, we've SCUBA dived together, and undertaken the most sacred of modern manly bonding rituals: Playing through Halo's Co-op Campaign on Legendary difficulty. He was my inspiration to get better at video games, and sports, and we've been up until 3 AM countless times arguing the finer points of moral philosophy.

item.title: My Perfect Day
item.description:
So, I thought I'd set down exactly where I want to end up in 10 years or so, so I can at least have a bit of direction, and know what I ought to be doing in my life to set myself on the right road, rather than just bump around aimlessly.

Predawn Meditation

I wake up just before dawn, energized and alert, in a house I built, and throw on a handmade parka before heading out the door barefoot and going for an early morning jog through the forest, which is only a few hundred yards from my front door. The air is damp but cool. I jog about ten minutes to my favorite rock overlooking a valley, facing the rising sun, where I sit and meditate as the sun comes up. I'm cold, but it doesn't bother me.

Jogging back, I stop on the way to feed the chickens and the goats wandering the yard. The dog is awake by now, but not the rest of the family, and he comes out to help me rouse the animals, playfully yipping at the goats and nudging the sleepy hens. While I'm out, I check the nests for eggs for breakfast. I finish tending to the animals and head inside to start preparing breakfast for the kids and the wife.

item.title: What I Don't Know
item.description: I don't know whether I'm qualified to define a morality for all young people, or even why I care so much. I figure it's as much for myself as for others. I don't know why it gets harder to achieve your potential after childhood, how to balance pragmatism and idealism, when high standards bleed into obsessive perfectionism. I don't know if anything I say applies to girls, or why more girls comment on what I write even though the image of a warrior is masculine to me.

item.title: The Minimalist Warrior
item.description: I've been playing God of War II (a video game, for the un-initiated). In this game, the main character, Kratos, begins the game as the recently appointed god of war, replacing Ares. He has all sorts of powers, wears nifty armor, and has a lot going on in his life. But he is not satisfied. Then, Zeus betrays him. There is a scene of Kratos' armor falling apart, leaving him with nothing but a loincloth, some boots, and his weapons, which is the state he goes through most of the game in. He has a single purpose at that point: to enact vengeance on Zeus. Kratos is a relatively small guy, as far as Greek heroes go - in a face off with Theseus, the Thebian towers over Kratos. Most of Kratos' enemies are decked out in fancy armor, carry ridiculous weapons (usually turned on them by the plucky Spartan), and have access to all sorts of assistance and special powers. Kratos is a minimalist. He powers his way through his environment, using his physical strength and his mental cunning, two simple blades, and little else.

item.title: How I Find Time to Write
item.description: I know that lately, I haven't been posting as regularly as  I used to. I've felt the consequences. My readership has declined, and I feel like my writing style has gotten a little stiff from lack of flexing. Writing has always been a hugely important part of my life. Not only is it an artistic means to express myself, it has always been associated with periods of balance in my life; when I'm writing regularly, my mind and spirit are in order, and a lot of other things as well. When I can't find the time to write, things slowly come apart at the seams. I don't really know why this is. Perhaps writing is how I parse my jumbled thoughts into discrete, comprehensible units called words and sentences, which I can then manipulate and act on in my life. Without taking the time to do this, my thoughts and ideas just fill to the brim and overflow in a messy jumble of psychic disorder. Writing is a form of meditation, a kind of waking dreaming for me.

item.title: In the Aftermath of Wino
item.description: Five rounds for time: 21 thrusters @ 75lb 21 double unders

item.title: More Job Offers, and Professional Integrity
item.description: Too much of a good thing can be problematic. Such is the case with job offers. I was recently offered a position at Forbes, where I have been helping out on the social media team in exchange for experience. I very much appreciated the offer, and my first instinct was to immediately accept. But I had made other commitments that I didn't feel entirely comfortable walking away from on such short notice. So I declined the offer. I've gotten reactions ranging from disbelief, to surprise, to admiration, to declarations of my stupidity.

item.title: Pigeonholing Myself
item.description:
In high school, we have so many dreams and activities. In order to be competitive for college, we fill our transcripts with a crazy variety of activities: math club, Boy Scouts, flying lessons, karate, cross country, guitar, piano lessons. This is in addition to our classes, which tend to cover a wide range of subjects: precalc, biology, English, painting. Then in college, we start off with a fairly broad range of topics to study, and as we move towards our major, the subjects narrow down to one or two: psychology and international studies of the Middle East. Then, after college, we get a job and are expected to become experts in one single field.

I used to consider myself a renaissance man, with interests in a wide range of activities, but I'm not so sure anymore. After all, I spend so much of my time studying fitness and in training. My conversations with people tend to gravitate towards talk about health, fitness, and nutrition. Last night while bartending,  a guy at the bar wanted to watch the NFL draft, and I had no clue how to have a conversation with him. I never really followed or understood football, but it made be wonder if I'm either out of touch with society or simply too narrow in my interests.

item.title: Integrity: There is more to Life than Winning...There's being Awesome!
item.description: Since the CrossFit sectionals I've been feeling considerably less motivated about my training. You'd think that making it to regionals would give me a message that I have some potential, and that I should work hard to realize it. Instead, I feel oppressed by the prospect of competing again. All my training is geared towards this one event, an event that has a very narrow definition of success (even by the standards of CrossFit), and in which I will undoubtedly be one of the smallest, puniest, guys there. Maybe I'm over-dramatizing here, but I definitely feel like an underdog - I'm young, relatively weak (most guys at these things can deadlift 400+ lbs, I'm around 315lb on a good day), and pretty inexperienced. If it's all about who can move the most weight, I'm screwed.

item.title: Traits of a Warrior: Persistence
item.description:
Today, the workout at my gym was to determine at what weight you could do 10 non-stop power cleans (move a barbell from floor to shoulder in one motion). At 165lbs, my form began to slip and I dragged the knurled bar up my shins, several times, leaving my legs bloody and stinging. I failed the set, only getting 9. Pretty upset with myself, I went to the bathroom to clean up.

As I was taping up my leg, I was thinking about calling it a day. But looking at my leg, I realized there wasn't any actual damage. All I'd done was scrape some skin, and while it stung, it had no impact on my muscles' ability to perform. I covered the wound in tape to protect it, and got back on the pad, and did the full set as if nothing had happened.

There are a lot of times in our lives when we suffer dramatic and painful failures. Our usual response is to throw in the towel, grudgingly accept that we did our best, and nurse our wounded egos. But when we look back, it is clear that our egos were the only things that were really injured by our setback. Our ability to complete the task at hand has not been diminished in any way, we simply have decided, arbitrarily, that we have failed.

item.title: Skills and Wills
item.description: Cool blog post by Seth Godin inspired me to think a bit about something that has been on my mind since I was a kid. In my conception of my future were two warring images of my adult self. One was an extremely independent explorer/traveler/innovator who set his own schedule, had plenty of free time, and an inexplicable, substantial source of monetary income. The other image was one of a diligent, creative and hardworking member of a larger organization with an obvious source of substantial income and less free time.

item.title: Crossfit New England Sectionals: Play-by-Play
item.description:
Okay, here it is, for everyone who wonders why I haven't been able to walk for the past two weeks (for the busy, the important bits are at the end, but workouts 2 and 4 are pretty juicy):

Day 1:

Workout 1:

  • Run 800m
  • 30 Snatches at 115 lbs
  • Run 800m

item.title: Missing What I Never Had: My Connection to the Real Food Community
item.description:
I have an interesting relationship with the sustainable food community. I am deeply passionate about it, but I have never actually been a part of it. I can practically come to tears reading Mother Earth News and get lost in stories about people raising heritage chickens, constructing their own homes,, tending gardens, living in harmony with nature and experiencing a familial closeness that few Americans ever experience anymore. But I have never done any of these things. I think I grew some bean sprouts once in elementary school.

Despite this apparent lack of connection, every time I read these stories or talk with people who live these lives, I feel an unmistakable sense of nostalgia. It seems strange to feel nostalgic for something I've never experienced, but I strongly miss these things. I miss raising chickens, I miss knowing the names of the trees and what they are good for, I miss being in tune with the seasons. It is as if a quiet part of me, long dormant, stirs every time it hears something related to how things used to be. There is a spiritual connection to that life of harmony that is so powerful in me it almost hurts to live a life that is not in accordance to its desires. But where did it come from? Has it always been there, as a primordial connection to the land and community inherent in all humans?
