Or is it something that grew in me in response to the decay I see in our disharmonious world and the hope offered by a return to a different lifestyle whose values so closely mirror my deepest ideals?

item.title: Mental Toughness, and the CrossFit Northeast Sectionals
item.description: I just got back from two days of the most intense physical and mental challenges of my life, the CrossFit Northeast Sectionals, the first step on the road to the 2010 CrossFit games, the winners of which are considered the fittest man and woman on Earth. I'm too tired right now to write a detailed play-by-play, so right now, I just want to share some thoughts. I was certainly one of the smaller guys going into this competition, and I have only been CrossFitting for a little over a year.

item.title: Two Ordinary Heroes: Me and My Dad in the Storm of 2010
item.description: This past week has been pretty hard on everyone in Southwestern Connecticut. My dad and I had a little adventure of our own, which I wanted to share, not so much because I want people to know as because I want to write it down somewhere. This blog has become my journal, so here it is. Just a Regular Day in Connecticut Around mid-afternoon last Saturday, our power went out. My mom had just pulled a chicken out of the oven, and was braising a boar loin, so we were pretty upset at the inconvenience, but weren't especially concerned.

item.title: The Point of the Clock
item.description: Today, after our workout, Kristi, my coach, Nick, a fellow CrossFitter, and myself stuck around to discuss the upcoming sectionals.  Somewhere in the discussion, the topic of different gyms' methodologies came up. The other Stamford-based CrossFit gym, Hybrid Fitness, believes that extreme strength is pretty much the fundamental requirement for a good athelete. As such, they utilize a lot of strongman programming and training. We do not, and generally we aren't as strong on average. Does that mean we are worse than them?

item.title: Bad Things Can Happen to Good People
item.description: A lot of people who restrict their diet for the sake of health have little to console themselves with when they must forgo all the little pleasures in life. All they can do is remind themselves that they will be spared the debilitating chronic diseases that will likely afflict their less-disciplined friends. Unfortunetly (or not) it isn't that simple. Sometimes, those of us with the healthiest of habits end up the victim while our chain smoking, sugar-munching friends live their whole lives without the smallest issues.

item.title: Just One Bite Won't Hurt, Will It?
item.description: Working at Zara has gotten me thinking about the ethical place of fashion (what, you mean you don't develop philosophical treatises when you fold clothes?). Basically, my dilemma is this: should I invest my time and money in looking stylish and thus promoting myself socially, potentially leading to financial and personal success as a result of my social finesse, or should I spare the environment and my checkbook by only buying functional, practical, and minimal clothing?

item.title: Book Review: The Game, and Dating Advice for Men
item.description: With the recent popularity of Neil Strauss's book, The Game, there has been a lot of backlash against what some call 'dating advice for men' and others (usually women, to be fair) call 'coaching men to take advantage of and manipulate women.' The book is subtitled, Penetrating the Secret Society of Pickup Artists, and that pretty much sums up what it is about. The author undertook to learn the ways of pickup artists for a year, ended up becoming one of the greatest pickup artists in the world (according to an internal rating), developed his own system, and eventually stepped out. He then wrote a book about his experiences, triggering a massive outpouring of additional pickup methods, books, how-to's, workshops, dating coaching seminars, etc.

item.title: Warrior Profile: Comparing Batman and Spiderman
item.description: I talk a lot about Batman as an inspiration for training and following ideals, so just for fun, I thought I'd write a post on how exactly the Path of the Warrior can be discerned from his life. To make things more interesting, I will be comparing him to another popular superhero: Spiderman. I picked these two because a) they are very nearly opposites without one being a villain, and b) there were recently made several movies about each.

item.title: Epic Fail
item.description:
Today, I failed epically. The workout for today:

As many rounds as possible, in 10 minutes, of

  • 7 deadlifts
  • 7 hang cleans
  • 7 front squats
  • 7 push jerks
  • All with 95 lbs

Basically, it's a ton of work, and much of it involving very technical movements. I was aiming to complete 7 rounds (so 49 of everything) because the previous record was 6 and change.

I completed 6 rounds with about a minute and a half left. I was already dying. My vision was blurry and my legs felt like jelly, but I pushed through the sets. I got to the push jerks with 30 seconds left and without taking any rest, started into them. As the clock ticked to 0 seconds, I became distanced from my body, aware of but not feeling the burning in every muscle (a sensation that I had never experienced before), until the very last rep.

item.title: Separating the (Young) Men from the Boys
item.description:
Growing up, my conception of what kind of man I would become was always very different from that of my peers. When I was in elementary school, I was emulating my idea of what responsible adults acted like, rather than trying to grow up to be like the high school kids. I didn't look forward to high school and college as times to party and sleep around, but instead as opportunities to start developing the skills and qualities I wanted to use as the foundation of my life as a responsible, formidable man.

My friends thought I was weird, and I thought I had made a huge mistake. I still wonder if I wouldn't have been better off just going with the flow and enjoying myself, instead of trying so hard to grow up.

item.title: Acknowledging My Spiritual Debts
item.description: [caption id="attachment_427" align="alignright" width="180" caption="Martin Prechtel"][/caption] An old friend sent me a link to a really profound article yesterday. The article is an interview with a Pueblo-turned-Mayan-shaman, Martin Prechtel. In the interview Prechtel discusses his relationship with the spiritual world of indigenous cultures that have a respect for, and connection to, the land and environment around them. He also draws some really ominous connections between the utter lack - some would say, outright denial - of spirituality in Western civilization and the cultural malaise we experience in the form of endemic depression, poverty, loneliness, and even physical ailment.

item.title: Lessons I've Learned
item.description: Sometimes the lessons you learn are harsh, and sometimes they are just surprising, but there is no point in denying reality. So here are a few partially inconvenient truths I've managed to internalize over the past few years.

item.title: The Ties That Bind
item.description: In my path down alternative fitness and nutrition and spirituality, I'm discovering that members of my various communities all seem to agree on certain things. Most CrossFitters tend to agree that we should move as our bodies were meant to, and often think in terms of evolutionary biology and anatomy. This parallels a similar trend in the local and traditional food community to look back to how our ancestors ate to determine the best way to eat now. In fact, the CrossFitters also extend this mentality to nutrition, and I'm sure many traditional foodies would as well if fitness were as central to their lives as nutrition is to a CrossFitter's.

item.title: My Paleo Journey
item.description: My gym's 30 Day Paleo Challenge has come to an end, though I know many of us will continue to stick to the diet, having seen a lot of progress in the last month. A number of my fellow CrossFitters didn't make it all the way though. The same attitude that gets them through grueling workouts is now making them very frustrated with themselves and their perceived inability to stick to a simple diet plan. They can't understand why a slice of toast is more difficult to overcome than a 250lb barbell.

item.title: Never Work a Day in Your Life
item.description: There are some jobs you would do regardless of whether you were paid or not. And then there are some jobs you would only do if you were paid. I'm a little shocked and terrified at the number of people who are paid to perform the functions necessary to making our civilization run, who perform jobs I can't imagine spending eight years of my life doing. I am torn between admiration for their ability to keep upbeat and cheerful and pity at the sheer tedium of their jobs. But we all have to make a living.

item.title: Traits of a Warrior: Humility
item.description:
One of the most important lessons I've learned from CrossFit is humility. Workouts that sound easy never are, and I am always amazed at how quickly my muscles will tire, how a weight that sounds light quickly becomes unbearable. To make things worse, we are always talking about how some crazy CrossFitter completed the same WOD in unrealistically fast times. CrossFit is a community, and so we know that the same workout that destroyed everyone at our gym was a walk in the park for someone else. Personally, this is hard to swallow. I know I've made amazing strides since I started, but an unweighted barbell still gets painfully heavy after a few minutes, and burpees can still leave me begging for mercy.

To make things worse, I've come to learn that getting frustrated does not make things any better. After 5 months of training, my snatch max hasn't changed a single pound. But trying to use frustration to motivate myself only causes my technique to fall apart. There is a fine line between determination and frustration.

item.title: Food and the Way of the Warrior
item.description:
I post a lot of talk about food and healthy eating on this blog, so you may be wondering what food has to do with the Warrior lifestyle. After all, it is such a mundane topic. Wouldn't our time be better spent discussing mental attitudes or physical training?

Food is important to a Warrior lifestyle because it is the basis of our physical existence. Food is used to contruct our bodies, and to fuel them. In order to be of service to others, and for her own happiness, a Warrior should seek to cultivate and maintain a healthy body. As much as we may deny it, we exist in the physical realm, and so must look after our physical existence to build a strong foundation for our endeavors.

item.title: On Grace
item.description: I used to do a lot of website design, not because I enjoy writing code, but because I like creative design. For me, there is a lot of pleasure to be had in discerning the best layouts for a page, the colors used to emphasize certain areas and ideas, the interplay of pictures and content in bringing your page to life. I was fairly well-versed in coding techniques as well, and was self-taught in HTML, CSS, and even a little JavaScript. I actually would get pretty involved in the technical side of things just to make a particular button or layout work the way I wanted it to in a clean, efficient manner. But set me down to write a piece of code with the express purpose of calculating and out putting some value and I’ll just fall asleep. For me, the allure is in the artistic possibility, the connection between the technical and the aesthetic. I find it fascinating how manipulating the very dry and cold elements of HTML and CSS code can produce a work of art. The process is very different than that of working with a brush, in which your actions translate directly to the art being produced. In web design, you are a step removed from your creation.

item.title: When it Rains it Pours
item.description: I've been out of college for a little over six months now, and looking for a job since September with zero luck. Sent out dozens of applications, trolled family contacts, bugged family friends, tried my hand at insurance, utilized alumni connections, everything I could think of. I don't even know how many Craigslist ads I responded to (in quite a bit of detail I might add). I went through a long and intense interview process for a job that would have set me down an amazing career in diplomacy and provided an astounding starting salary, only to be told eventually I lacked experience. My hopes have been dashed against the rocks more times than I want to count, but, with nothing else to do, I kept at it.

item.title: Superhero Training
item.description:
People ask me why I train so hard. The answer is simple. I'm training to be Batman... (as Superman was technically an alien, it would be a bit ridiculous for me to train to be him, since there's no way I could ever achieve that level of strength and fitness as an Earthling).

My CrossFit coaches have offered to pay my registration fee for the New England CrossFit Sectionals in March. While those who know me can attest to the fact that I didn't really need much motivation to train hard in the past, going to the Sectionals has given me a new kind of motivation and intensity to train. Knowing that I am going to be competing against some of the fittest people in New England, many of them bigger and stronger than me, has gotten me to really kick my training into high gear.

item.title: Taking Over Farm to Table
item.description: The sustainable food blog, Farm to Table, has recently been declared a failure by its creator. The initial goal, to set up a foundation for a TV show, did not produce results, and so he has decided to cut his losses and pursue another (really interesting) project. Never one to let things lie, I offered to take over and take Farm to Table in a new direction. So now I am the editor of Farm to Table, responsible for setting its direction and collaborating with the 1,000 or so followers.

item.title: An Unhealthy Fixation on Healthy Foods
item.description: I just heard a report on the radio of a new (2 years) tentative eating disorder called orthorexia, an unhealthy obsession with only eating healthy foods. First of all, I'd just like to say, that sounds ridiculous. Second, I believe it. Orthorexia can cause problems because sufferers frequently go hungry, choosing to starve rather than eat foods they deem unhealthy. Symptoms include trying out various (so called extreme) diets such as veganism, raw foodism, etc.

item.title: Book Review: I am Charlotte Simmons
item.description: Just finished Tom Wolfe's I am Charlotte Simmons, a disturbingly accurate depiction of modern American college life. The book is set in the fictional Ivy League University of Dupont, in Pennsylvania, and follows the first year of high school prodigy Charlotte Simmons. Charlotte, having won every award conceivable in high school, arrives at college with high expectations but finds herself overwhelmed by a world that cares more about social standing than academic achievement.

item.title: Would You Even Be Able to Say that to my Face?
item.description: Just found this interestging article in Times online, entitled, "Does Facebook Replace Face Time or Enhance It?" Considering I write a blog, which i share on Facebook and Twitter and which has engendered intersting duscussion at times, I thought I'd comment. The gist of the article is a dilemma between whether Facebook causes people to avoid interacting in real time or if it improves their real life relationships. The author describes his relationship with an old friend, which has degenerated to the point where she hasn't returned a phone call in over a year, but has poked him, sent him facebook gifts, and interacted in the various mini-games and applications on Facebook.

item.title: Don’t Take Nothin’ from Nobody
item.description: I'm currently reading Tom Wolfe's I am Charlotte Simmons, a magnificently detailed and richly described look at American college life. One of the main characters, Hoyt, is at the top of the college social ladder, a frat boy. His big claim to fame is the accidental witnessing of the visiting governor of California in a compromising situation, and a subsequent confrontation with the governor's bodyguard. The bodyguard challenged Hoyt and his friend, but instead of backing down, Hoyt took the question seriously, responding to the bodyguard "what do you two think you're doing?" with an honest answer. His confidence in his right to be there caught the bodyguard off guard, getting him angry enough to attack the boys, to his ultimate detriment.

item.title: What Books Do You Want Me to Read?
item.description: I want to get some suggestions for books you'd all like reviewed. Maybe it's something you've read but want to hear my take on it. Maybe it's something you'd like to read but haven't had time yet, or you want to see if it's good or not. Maybe it's just something you want me to read. Just leave your suggestions in the comment box. Fiction, non-fiction, anything.

item.title: Book Review: Zen and the Art of Motorcycle Maintenance
item.description: I recently completed the book Zen and the Art of Motorcycle Maintenance, by Robert M. Pirsig, which, contrary to its name, is not a book about Zen or motorcycle maintenance, except in a very roundabout way. The book is set in the motorcycle roadtrip of a father, the narrator, and his son, Chris, but the real meat of the book is contained in a series of chataquas, or talks, investigating a philosophical conundrum central to Western thought.

item.title: Learning to Stand Out
item.description: I have already talked about one aspect of the mindset associated with this post-college, recessionary jobhunt, that of having confidence in my employability. I wanted to share some recent developments in my strategies and the way I'm approaching things now.

item.title: Book Review: No More Mr. Nice Guy
item.description: A book I have recently read, No More Mr. Nice Guy by Dr. Robert A. Glover, adds to the growing conversation on masculinity in our society. Blogs like the Art of Manliness, the renewed interest in old-school shaving, the death of the metrosexual (maybe? hopefully) are all part of the movement to reclaim what it means to be a real man. Gover's book is an important contribution to that movement because it addresses one of the biggest stumbling blocks that recovering pansies have to deal with: the misperception that being a Nice Guy will get you anywhere in life.

item.title: How to Get a Job, and Charisma
item.description:
Like a lot of my fellow college graduates, I've been trying very hard to get a job in the past few months. And I spent the last month interviewing for one specific job that seemed like the perfect job for me right now. It paid a great salary, let me contribute to a cause I really cared about, was in New York City, where I want to live, and would utilize my skills and provide me with a lot of opportunities.

I spent a month and a half in the interview process, got called back twice, spent about $100 in train fare, spent hours crafting writing samples, researching the field and interview techniques, cultivating relevant connections, and going beyond what I was asked...and I was refused. My theory is that I should not have shaved my beard.

item.title: Intellectual Honesty
item.description:
Since starting this blog, I have constantly run into the problem of how honest to be with my readers. My parents are constantly asking me to tone down certain things, to refrain from sharing personal details of my life I think are important to understanding my thought process. I don't really know where to draw the line.

I had a conversation the other day with a friend who works in advertising. She is very supportive of my blogging, and every time I come up with an interesting idea, she encourages me to blog it, to share it with the world. My latest idea was somewhat risque, to put it lightly, but she said that was precisely the point. By being open and honeset about the truth of my life, I would be able to achieve a degree of integrity in my intellectual and emotional life that had eluded me.

item.title: Was Going to College a Mistake?
item.description: I am in the midst of reading Zen and the Art of Motorcycle Maintenance by Robert M. Pirsig, and the author spends a lot of time talking about the educational system in the United States, indeed, all of Western civilization. As a recent college graduate, this is something I've actually questioned a lot myself. I don't know about most of my peers, but I never really thought of college as a necessity, or even a forgone conclusion. When I applied to college, I did it in the context of an expectation - I went to a college-prep school and was at the top of my class, everybody at that school expected me to go to college - but I personally did not necessarily want to go to college. I chose to go, consciously, because I was convinced that it would help me achieve my goals. I did, however, entertain other options.

item.title: Traits of a Warrior: Service
item.description: Throughout history, Warriors have been the guardians of their societies. They do not train and fight for the sake of it, or for senseless violence. Historical warriors have learned the arts of war in order to better protect their people and families, or to extend their reach of their chosen sovereign. Tribal warriors were the ones who put their lives on the line to defend their families. Knights and Samurai were the ones willing to die for their lords' agenda.

item.title: Learning to Relax
item.description:
I'm finally back from Switzerland (actually, I've been back a while, but these posts have been backlogged), and I have come back a changed man, though I didn't realize I was changing at the time.

Going to Europe, I was not especially concerned about my ability to eat healthy, because I know the Swiss are very protective about the quality of their food. Staying in shape seemed like it might be a challenge, and the school gym proved pretty disappointing, but the Swiss have a reputation for lifelong hardiness, so I figured I'd absorb something through the mountain air. My biggest concern was fitting in with my sister's crowd. She has regaled me with stories of crazy nights out late at bars and dance clubs, which are not normally my favored scene.

item.title: Zermatt and Snowboarding Pictures
item.description: [gallery columns="4"]

item.title: Florence and Pisa
item.description: Lia and I went to Florence last weekend. I had never been to Italy, and I thought, since I'm in Europe, I might as well go see the country that fostered one of the world's greatest empires (so my decision was heavily influenced by watching too many episodes of Rome). Florence was a beautiful, crowded, lively city with narrow windy streets shared equally with cars and pedestrians. Random piazzas dominated by massive cathedrals and palazzos punctuated the city, setting the tone for each area.

item.title: You Must Dream
item.description:
This evening, I had dinner two friends of mine. The conversation with one was inspiring and empowering. The conversation with the other was considerably less so.

One purpose of this dinner was to talk about a potential job I am looking into, working for Arab-Israeli peace. Perhaps the most ridiculously idealistic endeavor anyone could undertake in this world. And that was my second friend's opinion. The position of the organization I've been looking at is that there is a moderate position, that it is a widespread position, and that there are enough Arabs and Israelis willing to accept it. My second friend expressed his opinion that this was unrealistic, and that there was too much history and too much animosity on both sides to enable any sort of reconciliation. Needless to say, he was not too excited about my new opportunity.

item.title: The Attractor Factor
item.description:
"I never think about ways to quit or lose. I only think about what I need to do to win!"

- Bill Whittle

I spent the weekend at a Primerica event in Parsippony, NJ, listening to the ideas and motivational life philosophies of Bill Whittle, the third highest earner in the company and one of the most successful men in the business. The great thing about Primerica is that so much of the business, which focuses on enabling individuals to achieve financial independence, is about personal growth, rather than business strategy or money-making techniques.

item.title: Traits of a Warrior: Excellence
item.description: This is the first in a series of posts on the attributes that make up this character we're referring to as a Warrior. These are the things that I seek to embody in how I live, the most important aspects of the men and women who seek to challenge injustice in society and who seek to bring about change. For that is what being a Warrior is all about: fighting the good fight, whether that be in the political arena, the social sphere, or the battlefield.

item.title: Four Books that Changed my Life this Summer
item.description: I did a lot of growing this past summer, and a lot of that growth was directed by some very, very good books. These have come up at least once in every serious conversation I've had since then, so I thought I'd post some explanation for the benefit of my friends who keep hearing about them. Each of these books has undeniably changed the way I think about life, for the better, widening my perspective or giving me the mental tools to better understand and grasp certain aspects of life.

item.title: The Zone Diet
item.description: In my CrossFit research, I recently came across a CFJ article in which Dr. Barry Sears, the founder of the Zone Diet, explains how it impacts athletic performance. Since it is the diet endorsed by CrossFit, it is not surprising that it improves athletic performance. What is interesting is that it is contrary to traditional notions of athletic diets. Most athletes, especially endurance athletes, who are not trying to lose weight, will either eat anything they want (because they just burn it off) or maintain a very high carb to protein ratio, gorging on pasta and granola.

item.title: Halloween
item.description: All Hallow's Eve was spent introducing my old high school friend to the Wii while answering the doorbell for trick or treaters. Kids these days have apparently developed a sense of entitlement. Doorbell rings, I open door, they stick out their bags and grab candy. No "trick or treat" no "Happy Halloween", just give me candy. To be fair, a few of them actually went through the ritualistic greeting. We even had one kid ask to use our bathroom, but it turned out we had no toilet paper stocked so he just left.

item.title: Just Say 'No' to Protein Shakes
item.description: I have noticed, in my path to attain some proficiency in high-level fitness, that there is an assumption that you need a lot of gimmicky science to get really good at anything. If you want to gain a lot of muscle, there best way to do it is to chug a 'specially formulated' protein shake after every workout, which itself is systematic and 'specially formulated' to give you maximum results with minimum effort.

item.title: Starting down the Path of the Warrior
item.description: What is the Warrior Spirit? First off, let me define what I mean by warrior in this context. The word itself is derived from War, organized violence, so a warrior might be someone who knows how to fight. At its simplest, this is true, but when you take into consideration the prerequisites of knowing how to fight, it soon becomes apparent that a warrior is much more than simply a soldier.

Problem-solving Process Spend some time with the problem “What would make this easy?” Make it like something familiar Make it concrete Test Look for shortcuts and refine What worked? Why? Can it be combined with something else or consolidated? What didn’t work? Why? Do I need that? Can we bypass the problem entirely? What should be changed to improve? Is that feasible? Repeat with a smaller version of the big cycle.
